text:
We found this to be a wonderful way to prepare eggplant. My husband who doesn't like eggplant raved about how good it was. I cut my eggplant very thin, salted it and let it sit for 20 minutes before preparing. In order to get my eggplant crispy like we like it, I glazed a metal pan with olive oil, cooked at the recommended temperature for 10 minutes and then turned the eggplant over and increased the temperature to 400 degrees for another 10 minutes. I also cooked it covered until the last 10 minutes so the cheese didn't burn. We liked this dish very much. Thanks for sharing!

country:
None
text:
Wow!  I've made this 3 times since finding this gem.  Once was for a meeting my boyfriend had to chef for - he took in a huge pan of it and came home with none.  And he had a couple requests for the recipe.  Regular eggplant parm is so awful for you because the eggplant basically acts like a sponge with the oil, soaking up as much as it can hold - This is an amazing variation that cuts all that fat out.  It doesn't taste exactly like the fried stuff - the eggplant doesn't get as soft - but it's great when you're not willing to give up eating for two days so you can have the real deal.  :o)  Definitely salt the eggplant in a colander, let it sweat for about 20 minutes, and then rinse and dry before continuing on.  It makes the eggplant taste much less bitter.

None
text:
OMG....over the top delish! Don't bother salting the eggplant as some have suggested and save yourself an unnecessary step.I followed the recipe exactly, used jarred marinara sauce and everything was perfect. Cooked exactly as stated. Some reviewers complained of soggy eggplant. If you don't salt it and use the sauce very sparingly you will have perfect eggplant. I did remove the skins as i have an aversion to them...otherwise followed it EXACTLY...sprinkled a little chopped fresh parsley in bottom of dish and on top. Did not layer all over the dish, just made individual stacks which I think prevents soggy cooking too.

city:

country:
None
text:
Omg !!!! This was fantastic. I Read alot of reviews first to see what others said  so I will tell you how I made it way better than any restaurant eggplant i have ever had .  I only made enough for my husband and I and our 2 yr old daughter. I bought 1 med sized eggplant and believed that it was the male one i asked the produce guy at Sprouts. I  
1 jar of traditional marina sauce , and 2 eggs , i did blend the italian bread crumbs with some plain panko to give it a crispy texture and also added some garlic powder and sprinkled fresh italian seasoning as well . I baked the eggplant on a cookie sheet sprayed with pam so it would not stick and baked at 425* for 10 min on each side  then followed directions from there on out. I paired it with some spaghetti squash and it was probably one of the best meals i have Made &  my husband is super picky and he even liked it and requested it again:) p.s i did sweat my eggplant first no bitterness at all 5 star recipe in my opinion.

text:
I dont like dry eggplant.....If i dont fry, i put olive oil all over the sheet and then bake.  I turn over and drizzle oil on the other side.  This way you get some browning and crispness to the eggplant.  Its like the old way of serving eggplant parm.  Thanks

text:
This recipe as written is definitely not quite right in terms of execution.  If you read the comments, you'll see that changes are needed in how the eggplant is prepped, how it's baked, and how the dish is layered in order to get best results.  You need to read and take notes on at least a dozen comments here just to get a decent dish.  For a first-time eggplant parmesan maker like me, it was really difficult trying to figure out whose advice to follow.  My advice is to search around for a recipe that is more helpful exactly as written, without needing a million modifications and input from dozens of other cooks. Next time I will look for a recipe from a pro chef.

Great recipe that I think would please even picky, anti-veggie people. Definitely worth trying!

text:
First time making this recipe so did not change anything except I never peel my eggplant and I use fresh basil.  This is an excellent dish and was quite easy to make.  My personal preference is Ichiban eggplant for flavor and texture and uniform slices and have never had one taste bitter. In future, when making it again, I will probably use yellow cornmeal in lieu of bread crumbs and add Italian seasoning to the cornmeal.  Yellow cornmeal gives eggplant a much heartier taste whether baked or fried.

I don't like subjective words in a recipe. Thinly sliced- I had no idea how thin that should be so I slivered it.  That was a lesson learned.  I tried to "sweat" the slivers but that was insane.  LOL.   I should have peeled the eggplant but my mom always used the the skin in her dishes.   A LOT of work, part of it my fault.  In the end, it looked and smelled so good and my husband and I liked it.  Only 2 of our 3 children ate it.  I will try this again because it was good but next time,  I WILL FOLLOW THE RECIPE, skip the sea salt recommendation (just peel the eggplant), cut the slices ~1/4 in. thick, and only use 2 smaller eggplants (3 was too much).  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
In the process of making ... 2 eggplants, 2c homemade italian crumbs (1c, 1/2t oregano, paprika), 2c homemade sauce, 3 egg whites (beaten till they looked soapy :D). 375 Thinly sliced must mean 1/4 inch or less.  I did mine thicker so longer baking time.  And if you get any crispiness without pamspraying it, you're better than me.  ;)  Okay, okay so the baked slices weren't too impressive; but once sauced & cheesed up they somehow managed to taste fried - meaning authentic.  Mystery here. The eggplants I used weren't particularly large so I don't think 3 would fit in a 9x13 - especially with the extra sauce & additional cheese.  Well, okay it might; but you'd have a mess in your oven.  :/  :)  For calorie-saving, it's a five star; taste, depends on your sauce & how big an eggplant parmigiana lover you are.  Kids, 13 & 15,  finally tried & didn't go for it.

userID:
1198645
Display Name:
Jajam
isPro:

followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6937904.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It seems that many are reviewing the baked slices rather than the finished recipe. I made this as written. The baked slices were slightly on the dry side, but plumped up once baked in the sauce. I give this 4 stars based upon ease for a family meal, but not as good as when the slices are "sweated" by salting, resting, rinsing and drying before breading. The final result also depends upon the quality of your tomato sauce. If you choose to salt eggplant (I have done on other recipes), it draws the moisture out (but oddly enough makes it more moist), collapsing the cells & making the eggplant "meatier" and resistant to absorbing excess oil. It is a nice touch if you have the extra time.

text:
Awesome... and so easy.  Do take another reviewer's advice and initially bake the coated eggplant on an olive-oil coated baking sheet (I needed two sheets) at 450 for 7 min. per side.  Then lower the heat to 350,assemble the full dish, and bake until it is bubbly and yummy.  Served over wholewheat spaghetti and with a salad on the side, this was just delicious.  And SO much less oil than if it was fried.

This is a good & simple recipe, and I love that it's baked rather than fried.  The key is the cut the eggplant very thinly, and precook them for 7 min on each side before layering.  I only used 12oz of mozzarella and 1-and-a-half large eggplants, which was plenty for a 9x13 casserole dish.

userID:
7596286
Display Name:
sarah

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe -- this is the only way I will eat eggplant! Per other reviews, I salted 1/4" slices and let sit for ~30 minutes before patting dry. This improved the texture and removed any bitterness. I cracked some pepper on each side before dipping into the egg (yolks omitted), and used panko rather than standard breadcrumbs for extra crispness. I spritzed each side with olive oil spray and cooked at 400F, 10 minutes per side. I finished them off under the broiler (~3 minutes per side, or until golden brown). I used a garlic and herb spaghetti sauce, preheated, assembled everything in a baking dish, and simply finished under the broiler until the mozzarella was golden and bubbly. The eggplant was cooked to perfection!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wasn't sure I had done this right, but my husband exclaimed at the first bite! When I was making it, he seemed so disappointed there was no meat, but he loved the "eggplant  lasagna". I didn't have any bread crumbs, Italian seasoned or otherwise. I made so with crushed Raisin bran (without the raisins) and crackers to make the crumb mix. Seasoned it with salt, pepper and dried basil. Since I did try to slice the eggplant as thin as I could, the 5 minutes per side was fine. No problems with the eggplant sticking to the pan. I have to admit, this cereal/cracker mix coated a lot better than I expected! I also tried sweating the eggplant with salt as some recipes suggested. I was very happy with the outcome!

text:
My husband does not like eggplant, but he begrudgingly admitted to me today that this is the best eggplant parmesan he's ever had. (win!) I made a couple adjustments: I was out of breadcrumbs so I used 1/2 grated parmesan cheese, 1/2 cornflake crumbles and added a package of dried onion mushroom soup mix and after sweating the eggplant coated them with this mixture. I baked them at 450 for 7 min each side then followed the rest of the directions. I also added baby spinach. Amazing! I halfed the recipe, but it was all gone by mid day the next day. I will absolutely make this one again.

country:
None
text:
I didn't fry my eggplant, I dipped the slices in egg-wash, then flour, then egg-wash and then in bread crumbs but you can skip the flour since you're baking it. This is my first time trying to cook the eggplant without frying it and I must say it's very good. It is a little bit drier than fried but if you drizzle some olive oil on top of the slices before you stick it in the oven it will come out moist like you fried it but without so much fat. So I like the alternative to frying, much healthier for you. I don't use exact measurements, but that's probably because I'm just used to eyeballing it, so I don't expect these measurements to be exact, but they do help someone who is a rookie at cooking.

Display Name:
Jeff Drake

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1194548.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay, this is great food! But be careful! The recipe called for 4 cups of seasoned bread crumbs. I used Panko, which I seasoned myself, and only needed 2 cups! You could find youself witha  couple of cups os extra bread crums and no place to use them.   Also, the recipe didn't call for peeling or salting/rinsing the eggplant first. You don't have to do this if you have small/young eggplant. But eggplant skin can get tough on larger, older eggplants. And big eggplants can hold a lot of water. So make the right choice. I used 3 large eggplants and salted them and rinsed them. Perfect!

2
userID:
2416203
Display Name:
Ana
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
81
favoritesCount:
95
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Would give this 4.5 stars - it was really good.  The right ratio of ingredients seems to be 1 eggplant requires 1 egg, 1/2 cup of bread crumbs, 1/2 jar of pasta sauce, and 3-4 oz cheese.  I made my own Italian seasoning by adding, to each cup of crumbs, 1/2 tsp salt, ground pepper, 3/4 tsp garlic powder,  1/4 tsp onion powder, 1/2 tsp oregano, fresh chopped parsley, and fresh chopped basil.  I used a blend of mozzarella, provolone, asiago, and romano cheeses.  I sweated 1/4" eggplant slices for 30 mins in salty water, rinsed them, and patted them dry.  I baked them in 450 degrees for 7 mins per side.  Once I assembled the whole dish, I baked it for 29 mins and it was just at the point before burning (maybe next time I will lower to 350 degrees for the full 35 mins or bake at 450 for 25 mins).  However, texturally, there was nice contrast between the top piece of eggplant (really crispy and dried) vs. the bottom pieces (soggy and soft) - we actually liked it that way!  2 eggplants make approx 3 servings and 3.5-4 layers.  It went fast because we really enjoyed it.

text:
This was absolutely hands down the best eggplant parmesan I have ever eaten.  I love the fact there is no grease so all you taste are the true flavors.  I am out of dried basil so I used fresh and since I love basil, I used 1/3 cup chopped fresh basil, layering it on top of the eggplant and before the sauce. I sweated the eggplant first, peeled it too because I hate the skin.  The baking time of the eggplant itself needs to be increased.  It took me 15 minutes a side to get them crisp but I think that's my oven not the recipe.  I will make this again and again.  I think even my picky family members will enjoy this dish.

text:
This recipe is amazing.  I followed other's suggestions and sweated the eggplant before cooking and I detected no bitterness.  I also cooked it at a higher temperature - 400 for 14 minutes per side and it was nice and crispy without being burnt.  I've never cooked with eggplant before and was worried when I cut into it and saw seeds, but it didn't seem to affect the taste.  I used Prego Organic basil and tomato sauce to save time rather than making my own sauce.

Display Name:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the first time I have ever had eggplant Parmesan as well as my first time making it. I did use a couple of the tips from the other reviews.   I used my potato peeler to peel then I cut my eggplant in ¼ inch slices.  I used the sea salt for 20 minutes for removing the bitterness out, then rinsed and patted the eggplant really well.    I mixed up 5 eggs for dipping the eggplant in, and put my Italian bread crumbs in a Ziploc.  This made it much easier and less messy for breading my eggplant.  I baked the first batch of eggplant  for 15 minutes on each side, but it didn’t get as golden brown as I wanted it to, so I pan seared them   and the remaining in extra virgin olive oil.  This gave me the look I was looking for.  I placed them on a baking sheet in the oven at 3500 while I finished searing the remaining pieces (don’t layer them they will get soggy).  I love cheese so I added a two pound bag (32 oz) of shredded mozzarella cheese and 16 oz of shredded Parmesan cheese.  I used 4lb 3 oz jar of Prego Italian Sauce.  I put a light layer in the bottom of my glass pan (my pan is bigger than the 9x13) and layered it like lasagna ending up with cheese on the top, and baked it on the bottom rack at 3500 for the 35 minutes.  Wow!!!!  it was so cheesy and  so delicious.    My family loved it and it made lot we had it for dinner the next day over a bed of pasta.   Oh it was fantastic that way too I’m not sure which way I like better.   This is a killer recipe and definitely wo

country:

text:
I salted the eggplant and dusted it off. Why rinse it with water when the salt is removing the excess water from the vegetable itself? Just resist adding more salt to your sauce. I always leave the skin on since it contains  an "anthocyanin phytonutrient, called nasunin. Nasunin is a potent antioxidant and free radical scavenger that has been shown to protect cell membranes from damage". Choose younger, tender eggplants for thinner skin. Also, look for an oval dimple on the bottom (versus round) this type of eggplant has less seeds--or so I've been told.

text:
Pretty good, but not exceptional. I followed the recipe almost exactly as written, my only changes were salting/draining the eggplant in a colander ahead of time and cooking the eggplant for a longer period of time in the oven before assembling the dish (I cooked 10 minutes per side). If I make this again I'll add an additional 8 oz. mozzarella and additional basil. I think the main problem is that this relies heavily on the taste of the tomato sauce and if that taste isn't good the entire dish is very so so. Next time I would definitely make sure to either substitute my own marinara sauce or to buy a very high quality store brand sauce.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've always made Eggplant Parmesan by frying before baking and found this alternative excellent. I don't think I'll ever make it the other way again. Plus it's less work because I don't have to do batches in my frying pan because largest my pan (13") isn't big enough fry all the eggplant at the same time. Skipping the frying made less mess in the kitchen overall, so I'm pleased with that as well. I did sweat the eggplant with salt before coating and breading and did have to bake it for 10 minutes to get it tender. I did miss the taste of olive oil infused in the fried eggplant, but it wasn't so obviously missing that I could easily get used to this new method.

text:
OUSTANDING RECIPE! I too followed a bit of advice from previous reviews and Sweat the 1/4" think slices by sprinkling with sea salt on both sides and letting stand for approx. 30 mins. Rinse, pat dry w/ paper towel making sure the get good & dry.
Also, Instead of baking, you can also pan fry (I used Canola oil) the eggplant until it turns a nice golden color and then proceed with Step 3 of the recipe.

This was just absolutely delicious!  If you love eggplant parm like I do, you have to try this. Display Name:
Ping A-Ling

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5335766.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I sweated the eggplant slices by salting them, leaving them for 30 min, then washing them off and squeezing dry with paper towels.  I used 2 medium sized eggplants which were enough for 9 inch baking dish if thinly sliced (1/4").  The slices have to be baked for at least 9 minutes a side to be nice and dry.  The slices turned out well since the texture simulated meat which my meat loving family needed in order to eat it.  I added mushrooms to my dish which I'm glad I did or else it would've been even more bland - I would recommend adding many more veggies to up the taste.  I used Shake and Bake Italian crumbs instead of italian breadcrumbs since I couldn't find any and it turned out fine.  I used Healthy Choice garlic and onion sauce but if you can, use homemade sauce since these bottled ones are so watery and bland.  Overall, this recipe was good because it was healthy but needs much more to be excellent.

text:
this was my first time cooking fresh eggplant... these were really great and were not a big production/intimidating as i had anticipated — super easy! my boyfriend loved it! we had it over angel hair pasta.

i used one medium-sized eggplant and i sweated the slices as several suggested for 30 minutes and added parmesan and garlic to the breadcrumbs (contadina). i double-dipped/breaded the slices and baked them for 10 on each side; they weren't very crispy/browned after 5. and used barilla's basic marinara sauce which worked well.

watch your cooking time for the whole casserole - mine only needed about 20 minutes. even though i only used 1 eggplant and my boyfriend had hearty seconds, we have a ton of leftovers and i set aside some of the slices for sandwiches - so good!

text:
This is a great recipe however I did modify it a bit to make cooking simpler. Please please sweat your eggplant for 30 minutes with salt ( takes away the wang that you can get form store bought eggplants sometimes)
Instead of a 9x13 pan I used two baking sheets and laid out my breaded eggplant and cooked for about 7 minutes on each side. Then I simply layered sauce on top sprinkled with parmesan and mozarella and cooked for 25 minutes. If you slice your eggplant about a 1/4 inch thick you will only need about 25 minutes in an oven that cooks well.
I served this amazing dish over buttered whole wheat spaghetti noodles with my homeade sweet sicilian sauce. Delish!!!!! As a new vegetarian I am looking for some good dishes so my family doesn't say "hey where's the meat"

madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:
68
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thank you to all of you who share your wonderful recipes here.
Regarding this recipe:
* I used Prego Traditional Sauce 2 x 24 oz bottles.
* I used fresh basil, cut up 1 big leave in small pcs
* I used 2 sml eggplants (other user said less seeds, less bitter, she was right).  
* Skinned 1 eggplant w/ potato peeler.  Took off top. Cut in 1/2 length wise, then in thin slices.  
I put the slices in a 1 gallon ziplock bag.
* Beat 1 egg which I added to 1 gallon ziplock bag.  Rubbed bag to make sure all pcs were covered.
* I added 1 C of plain bread crumbs and 3/4 C of seasoned bread crumbs.  Rubbing the bag to make sure all pcs were covered.
* Laid them out on a plate.
* Repeated these steps with 2nd eggplant.
* Followed the rest of the directions of the recipe.  
I tried some of the slices after frying and when I was done frying I put them in a 9 x 13 dish sprinkeled them with light salt and Italian seasoning.  Mixed them to make sure all pcs got some salt & seasoning.
Before putting in baking dish I divided: eggplant and cheese in 6 to make sure I had 6 equal amount of layers.
It turned out great.  This is for Sunday,  today is Friday, I hope I don't eat it all by then.

text:
This was pretty tasty but it did require some tweaking.  I found 2 eggplants to be more than enough for my family of four.  I added basil and Italian seasoning to the tomato sauce and I found that the eggplant needed to cook for about 10 minutes on each side.  I used park skim mozzarella slices because that's what I had on hand and I like the way they melt (the cheese gets nice and done like I like it).  I will make it again.

text:
I loved this eggplant! My boyfriend and I are trying to eat at least 2 vegetarian dishes a week, and this will be a huge help. I give the recipe 4 stars because I modified it slightly: I used homemade sauce, which I think made a big difference to the taste. I also used fresh basil, because I had a ton on hand, and sprinkled a layer in the middle. I only had unseasoned bread crumbs on hand, so I made my own by adding italian seasoning, garlic powder and parmesan cheese. I think I used a little less cheese than called for, but I needed an extra egg to coat all the eggplant (maybe I cut it too thin?). Regardless, a great recipe that you can do a lot with! Thanks!

I am very impressed. First time to make this recipe and my picky father in law had seconds! Took the advice and baked it with a little spray olive oil on top and bottom at 425, got it good and crunchy so when all assembled it held it's form beautifully. Also, cut and peeled and sweated the eggplant the night before and then drained again the day I made it, cut down on prep time the day of making it. Family said keep!

text:
Turned out very well.  This was my first time making eggplant parmesan.  Made 1/3rd the recipe.  Made my own sauce and bread crumbs by adding 2T parsley flakes, 1/4 tsp red pepper, and 1 tsp each garlic pwd, onion pwd, dried basil, and dried oregano to 2 cups bread crumbs.  Used the same mix of seasonings with 2 quarts home canned crushed tomatoes and 1lb browned ground turkey and simmered it about a 1/2 hr.  Baked eggplant 10 min per side as recommended by other reviewers.

text:
This was very good.  I made a few modifications - As suggested by other reviewers, I sliced the eggplant (I used 2 good size eggplants), salted it and let it sit for 20 minutes, then I rinsed and patted dry.  I used egg substitute, instead of real eggs.  I baked the eggplant 10 minutes on each side and then turned the broiler on and broiled on each side for a minute and a half.  This made the eggplant a little crispy.  Other than that I followed the recipe.  My husband and I both really enjoyed this and we are looking forward to the leftovers today.

I havent had eggplant since my mother fixed it for me when I was 10, I am now 33.  Needless to say I guess I STILL dont like eggplant.  I thought I would try this recipe because of all the reviews that said they didnt like it but loved it in this recipe. I am sure this is a good recipe for those of you who do like eggplant.

My husband and I loved this. I couldn't find Italian bread crumbs so had to "make" my own. Display Name:
marysam

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first try at eggplant parm and it came out pretty darn good. We liked that it was baked, so was way less greasy than my usual fried eggplant slices. A couple small changes: first, I sliced it lengthwise instead of in circles, which made for nice even layers in the baking dish, similar to how lasagna noodles work. I did sweat the eggplant. Instead of bread crumbs, I crushed some panko with a rolling pin and mixed in some oregano and fine Parmesan. No basil! Let it sit for 15 or 20 minutes after baking, so it sets up nicely. That's it! Serve with linguini and marinara. Making it again this weekend with the last of the garden eggplants

Made it three times. Make sure you peel the eggplant and cut into slices then salt for an hour to remove the bitterness. Then rinse off the salt  and drain before dipping in the egg mixture. Taste great the next day as leftovers if you have any.

text:
Growing up in an Italian Family we never use jar sauce unless to make pizza. So I used my own sauce and it tasted great! I liked baking the eggplant instead of frying it to try & be  healthy. Frying the eggplant definitely gives it a crunchy texture and prevents it from getting soggy. This was a little soggy but overall very tasty. In the future, I may try broiling or air frying the eggplant to get that desired crunch.

helpfulCount:

userID:
20261205
Display Name:
MaryLou Veroline
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3842925.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night and my 14 year old who wanted pizza for dinner had two servings :) Agree that 1/4" is the perfect thickness, sweated the slices with salt on one side laying on paper towels. After 20 minutes, wiped slices but did not rinse. We are gluten free so while the eggplant was sweating, I toasted about 6 slices of rye style, gluten free bread and then made crumbs in the food processor. Did the egg dip, coated with bread crumbs by hand and baked for 20 minutes (on parchment paper) without flipping since the crumbs were larger and would have fallen off. Layered sauce on bottom, eggplant slices, mozza cheese, parm cheese, NO sauce, eggplant, cheeses, sauce, cheese, basil. Baked until heated through 25 mins or so. Amazing!!!!  I think the bread crumbs were the key because of the rye style bread and because no sauce in the middle to make them soggy.

None
text:
recipe tips: 1) You can eat the skin on young eggplants, but the skin of older ones can be bitter and may require peeling.
 2) The flesh of older eggplants can be bitter, too. To mitigate this, sprinkle salt on slices or chunks, and let them rest for 30 to 60 minutes in a colander until they begin to give up water. Rinse them well, pat them dry, and proceed with your recipe. 3) When you're not using the above technique, cut eggplant just before cooking, as its flesh quickly discolors. 

Variation: as another person stated "skip breading, frying or baking entirely. Simply slice them, brush with EVOO and grill on both sides until lightly browned. You can use the gas grill or a ridged grill pan or indoor griddle. It really cuts down on the fat, carbs and calories "

Great call to bake!  We love eggplant parm. Used the reviewers suggestion to use egg whites & made my own seasoned bread crumbs. I peeled 1 eggplant (we grew it) & sweated it on paper towels. Baked thick slices at 350* 10 min per side. Then made a casserole of a little homemade sauce in bottom layered with cooked ala dente whole wheat spaghetti placed baked eggplant on top then more sauce with sautéed Italian sausage with peppers & onions ! Covered everything with shredded mozzarella & grated fresh parm. Baked about 10 min until cheese browned. Definitely company worthy. Thanks  for ideas. A keeper! text:
I gave this 5 stars, first because it gave me the idea not to fry the eggplant. I was afraid it was going to be too dry or stick, neither happened. I'm not one to try to make things complicated when it comes to last minute menus, this was a last minute for me. I had one huge eggplant that I needed to cook tonight so it wouldn't go bad. (becoming much better not to waste my produce, it's struggle for me sometimes).  So I went to Allrecipes and searched for easy. This was easy. Perfect.  I followed the directions for egg, breading, and baking. I only had the one eggplant but it was rather big. I had enough for two layers. I used whole wheat seasoned bread crumbs but no matter what recipe I follow, I usually add the following dried ingredients, basil, garlic powder, oregano, for my "italian" dishes. I layered as suggested, baked in oven for 30 minutes, the first 20 minutes, I covered the baking dish with foil and then removed it to brown the cheese. I did not salt, soak, or peel the eggplant and I had no problems with it. The baking before hand seemed to do the trick. My adult son ate it and liked it, I ate it and loved it. He's not emotional as I with food.  Next time, I may attempt homemade spaghetti sauce. In my old age, I'm finally learning. I hate to go out to eat anymore, much prefer to eat my own food.

city:

country:

text:
My boyfriend and I tried this recipe last night and we really enjoyed it! We did run into a couple of issues and modified a few things. We had way too much eggplant. I bet you would be fine with getting 2 large-ish ones. In the video, it mentions salting the eggplant slices and letting them sit for 30mins to make them less bitter. I would suggest that, if you have the time. Also, start with 2 eggs in the bowl, but I bet you will need to crack more. I think I ended up having to use 4 or 5. We only had 3 cups of the bread crumbs and we were fine. When it came time for spaghetti sauce, we used Prego Florentine Spinach and Cheese. It was a nice little add on. It was thicker so it made the dish less watery. Overall, the recipe was fun to make, but make sure you have the time to work on it. Very tasty!

I'm a Vegetarian I was asked to bring a Vegetarian dish to a Church dinner. I live in the south where usually, just the word Vegetarian bring on a sour look and a snarled lip. Anyway I took this dish thinking I would just be bringing it back home. I watched, finally someone got up the nerve to try something labeled "Vegetarian". The look on their face was yum. This dish was a success in a place where everything has to be deep fried and buried in chili n cheese or sweet. Anyway great recipe that deserves all 5 stars.

text:
I had never made, let a lot eaten eggplant parm so I followed the recipe closely.  Did take other advice on sweating the e.p. and made my own sauce.  Thinly sliced to me is very thin so I did that.  Also baked for called for time.   The results were not good and had me wondering why people eat eggplant. Mine was leathery and not at all appealing.   

Made it again except this time my sister who is a full vegetarian was there to help me what it was supposed to taste like.   Sliced it at about a quarter of an inch and baked, baked and baked some more.  Didn’t keep track of the full cook time but it was far longer than stated.   The results were good and everyone including my teenage son enjoyed it.  

1 star if you follow the recipe – canned sauce and leathery eggplant, not our idea of a good meal.  With adjustments it’s a 5 star, thus the 2 star rating.

I totally loved this recipe but wasn't my all time favorite. Taste wise. Maybe it's cause I don't like eggplants but needed to cook this for my dad's diet.

I think the eggplants should be drained really well and should be soaked in salt then rested on a tissue. That's a must! It makes the bitterness go away and also gives a better taste to the eggplant. 

Over all, this was a successful recipe and I recommend it.

Like there needs to be another review on this recipe, but I just have to review it bc I am so happy!  Made this last night for dinner. Display Name:
C. Waite

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4508693.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Even with all of the positive reviews, I was shocked at how delicious this was. I did as someone suggested and ground oatmeal in my blendtec with some italian spices to use in place of the bread crumbs. Also as someone else had stated, used Hunt's Garlic and Herb spaghetti sauce. I added some red chile flakes and fennel seed to the sauce. Anywhere between 1/4 to 1/2 tsp. each. Cut 1/4 inch eggplant slices. To drain some of the moisture from the eggplant, I put them on a paper towel, salted one side, flipped them over and salted the other side. After sitting for a while, transferred them to new, dry paper towels. As someone suggested, I dipped the eggplant in some flour first. Baked @440* for 10 minutes each side. They turned out beautifully. Served over angel hair pasta. Oh so good!!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-02-06T14:49:21.157
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
11259332
Display Name:
EmmLee
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
40
favoritesCount:
37
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3570286.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it tonight, very good. As per my usual, I sliced the eggplant (wipe the knife off after cutting the stem and end off - that's where the bitterness comes from and will "spread" to the rest of the slices if you don't). I placed a single layer in a deep wire colander, salted each layer, and then placed a plate weighted with a bowl of water on top for about a half hour. Rinsed and dried well after. I dipped each slice in flour, then egg, then bread crumb mixture and baked on a greased cookie sheet for 10 minutes each side. I always save leftover homemade sauce in the freezer, and just defrosted a few containers to use for this recipe. Takes some time to prep, but we like it so much better than fried and using a low-fat Italian cheese blend gives lots of flavor. As does adding salt, pepper, garlic and onion powder and 1/4 c parm to the bread crumbs. We will deinitely be making this again.

text:
Made this on 22 Jan 14, read other reviews that suggested salting the eggplant (I did not peel the eggplant) and letting it rest for 20 minutes or so.  Which I did, for about and hour to remove excess water. I made a large portion, used 4 medium sized eggplants, 5 eggs, lots of cheese and 4 1/2 jars of spaghetti sauce (2 were basil flavored).  I cooked the eggplant for about 20 mins per side and assembled & baked for about an hour.  The end result was very yummy, a perfectly golden brown layer of cheese on top and a moist/saucy, cheesy inside.

text:
This is not the typical eggplant parmesan recipe, but we loved it.  I scaled it down to 1 eggplant to make only enough for 2 and it made enough for 2 1/2 meals. I served it over spaghetti noodles...I wish I would have had a bit more sauce for those, but it was still so good.  I used the suggestions of so many other reviewers and sprinkled the salt on the eggplant, left for 30 min. and rinsed to avoid any bitterness.  Then baked on each side for 10 min.  Other than that, it was prepared as directed.  We will have this again.

We tried this after my son said he wanted to try eggplant, and everyone loved it! I didn't soak the eggplant at all, no problems with bitterness. Also, my hubby is lactose intolerant, so after baking the eggplant slices about 15 min on each side, we served them over pasta with the sauce on top, and then the cheese. country:
None
text:
Wonderful recipe, only change two things.  First I peeled the eggplant and then sliced the eggplant.  I put a layer of sliced eggplant in a large colander and sprinkle evenly with salt. Repeat with remaining eggplant, salting, until all eggplant is in the colander. Weigh down the slices with a couple of plates and let drain for 2 hours.  This removes the moisture from eggplant before cooking.  And continued with the rest of the recipes.  Will make again and again!!

DELICIOUS!  Like many reviewers suggested, I salted the slices to remove bitterness, let them drain for 30 minutes then rinsed and dried the slices. text:
I have changed it a bit. Washed my vegetable well, left the skin on amd sliced it in the lenght, very thin.
Used the same breading and fried it in olive oil for just a minute to brown.
Sprayed a cookie sheet, added spagetti sauce on top followed by a mixture of italian cheeses and baked at350 for 10 min.
Excellent with a ceasar salad
The eggplant was crisp amd delicious
The 4 star is for the change

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This produced a wonderful dish and we liked that the eggplant was not deep fried. The texture of the final eggplant slices in the dish were just right, not too crunchy and not too mushy. However, the proportions and directions need major correction. We used 3 medium eggplants (the direction do not say what size eggplant to use). When thinly sliced three eggplants produce a lot of slices. I changed the proportions :
- 3 medium eggplants, peeled and thinly sliced
- 6 eggs, beaten
- 3 cups Italian seasoned bread crumbs (option; add 1/2 cup grated parmesean to the bread crumbs)
- 10 cups spaghetti sauce
- 24 ounces mozzarella cheese, shredded and divided
- 1/2 cup parmesean cheese
- 1/2 teaspoon dried basil
Also, in the Directions it says to bake for 35 minutes. This recipe produced so much that you need to bake it for 45 min. at 350 degrees.

text:
This recipe is DELICIOUS!  I have prepared it several times already for friends, family, and even a potluck and every time I make it I get asked for the recipe.  

I have made a few alterations along the way based on some great tips from the other comments I found here.  I salted the peeled and sliced eggplant to let it "sweat" and then rinsed and dried it before baking it and it helped cut down on the bitterness some.  Also, I added grated parmesan cheese to the breadcrumbs (about 1/4 cup) and a jar and a half of marinara sauce (I've found Newman's Own Tomato and Basil to be amazing in this recipe).  

This recipe gets 5 stars for turning even the most dedicated chicken lover into an eggplant parmesan fanatic. (

text:
Scrumptious! Trying to watch my sodium, I didn't salt (sweat) the eggplant as others have suggested. I used a regular sized lower sodium spaghetti sauce and mixed it about 50/50 with no salt added tomato sauce and it sttill came out great! ! I found spraying EVO on both the pan and on top of breaded slices helps them to brown better (I also used higher heat 375 for browning) and browning about 10 min each side., and lowered back to 350 for final baking of the finished product. Fun, easy and healthier way to enjoy a comfort classic!  Thanks for the greeat recipe!

As a new chef (studying abroad and missing my US college's dining hall), I was nervous to try a dish that I have always revered as tricky...but it was simple! For me, it was time consuming...but I'm new, so I'm slow. 
I had to convert all of the measurements myself, as the converter was not working well. Even with too much tomato sauce, this was simply delicious!
My friend asked me for the recipe!

Definitely follow the recommendations to let the eggplant slices "sweat" in salt and then be rinsed an dried before coating. And cook for 8-10 mins on each side.

A winner!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved this - ate the leftovers for days and still good.  I followed the tips of several earlier reviewers.  First I salted, drained and rinsed my peeled sliced eggplant.  After breading, I baked it in a hot oven for about 10 minutes or so on each side to get it crispy.  Finally, I made my eggplant parm into "stacks", as another reviewer suggested, instead of layering them into a entire casserole dish.  I really liked doing it this way because it was easy to separate into individual portions (No cutting the slices) without destroying the layers.  This was very useful to me as I saved so much of it for leftovers.  I also made sure my jarred sauce was yummy and spiced it up (added garlic, red pepper flakes, herbs, etc.) to my taste before using.  As usual, I used more cheese than the recipe calls for.  And, next time I make this, I'm going to take one more suggestion and make a lot of extra breaded and baked slices to freeze so that it will be even faster to put together thereafter.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Although Dad said I can make this any time, I probably won't.  It was not worth the trouble breading all the eggplant pieces.  I had never tasted eggplant before, and wasn't sure whether it's okay or terrible (which has no reflection on this recipe).  The proportions are not correct.  I used about 4.5 cups sauce, and I had enough eggplant for 3 layers.  Also, 2 eggs were not enough for the breading step and I had to use 3.  The breading did not get crispy in 10 minutes, and it did not stay on the eggplant, either.  It took much longer than 25 minutes to prepare (maybe I'm just slow).  Now I know why Mom never served eggplant while I was growing up--it's just not worth the effort.  Unless you LOVE eggplant, stick with lasagna for a cheesy, saucy casserole.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, so this was my first attempt at eggplant parmesan after I had it at a restaurant and loved it.... I love the recipe, BUT.... who is this recipe trying to feed??? LOL... I did this with 1 eggplant and ate for three days! 

anyway.. great recipe! I took the advice of several others and sweated the eggplant for thirty minutes. followed the instructions and the first day the eggplant was pretty undercooked. reviews were so-so... 

the second day I put it back in the oven(covered) for an additional hour at about 400 and the eggplant came out very tender and the dish was awesome! definitely cook it longer than is stated...

I still give it five stars because the recipe is delicious! if you like a more tender eggplant (like me), cook it longer than stated. 

I'll definitely make it again....

text:
though i modified the recipe..its a great base.  I made an egg wash and Dipped 12 slices of eggplant into it.  Next into breadcrumbs with a dash of salt, pepper and oregano.  Baked it in a pan lightly oiled, first side 20 mins; next side for 15 mins or until golden brown.
Sauce: ground turkey with minced garlic and onions and jar of prepared sauce
Arrangement:eggplant, sauce and mozzarella cheese and parmesan cheese x2
baked for about 25 mins or until cheese is melted. 
Served it with garlic spaghetti.
YUMMY! My bf loved it and went for seconds.
Next time i'm thinking of adding a spinach and feta mixture in the middle to add more flavor and use beef instead of turkey with a can of tomato sauce.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My go-to dish to fix for my vegetarian husband when company is coming. If you can get nice fresh eggplant - think farmers' market - I find I don't need to sweat the slices of eggplant before baking. If from the grocery store out of season, I will salt the eggplant, leave in colander for 20 min, then rise and pat dry, before dipping in the egg and bread crumbs. Three small/med eggplants make a bit more than my 9X13 pan, so I make a mini dish for the freezer that is just enough for my husband and I some night when there is no time to cook. I highly recommend this recipe.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish was not worth the very long time it took to make and cook. I followed the directions, and others' advice, and discovered the following: 
1) More egg is needed (4 eggs, not 2); 
2) Fewer breadcrumbs are needed (2 cups, not 4); 
3) Baking for 60 minutes gives a very dark, almost burned look to the top;
4) The eggplant came out too salty -- although I did salt the eggplant and let it sit, I also rinsed it well afterwards. Still, it seemed salty to me.
5) The whole process of making this dish took hours. Though my husband said it was tasty, I only liked it (didn't love it). All in all, I don't think this dish was worth the time and painstaking steps.

Just my two cents.

Oh my gosh!  SO GOOD!!  I had a reduced sourdough loaf of bread from Wal-Mart and toasted slices then put it in the blender to make crumbs. text:
This was awesome!  My husband and 4 y/o liked it too.  I used 1 eggplant.  Sweated it for 30 mins, rinsed and dried.  Then coated it with breadcrumbs and parmesan.  I baked on a pan coated with cooking spray at 425 for 7 mins on one side, 5 mins the other side.  It was PERFECTLY brown.  Then layered in a small casserole dish and heated through at 400 degrees for 20 mins.

text:
We really liked this.  I read a lot of the previous reviews first and took the advice of others to sweat the eggplant first.  I used all 3 eggplants that were suggested, but I feed an army, and there was enough for about 12 servings.  I did however use more cheeses and sauce.  I also used the Italian 6 cheese blend instead of just the mozzerella, and I think I may use some garlic next time.  I also chose to use fresh chopped basil instead of dried.  I also would love to try this again with homemade sauce.  I did, however find that this recipe (and the amount I was making) took longer than I had anticipated to make, so my poor husband ate his eggplant parmesean on a piece of garlic bread as he was going out the door to work.

text:
As other reviewers stated, the amount of eggs to coat the eggplant is way too low.  Be prepared to use several more.  I also thought that the amount of breadcrumbs that was asked for was outrageous (especially given the low egg count).  I coated each slice as thick as I could and ended up sprinkling the rest into the dish just so I wouldn't waste it.  I used the Safeway Brand Garlic Marinara, and to my surprise, it had huge cloves of garlic in the sauce, which I thought really added to the dish.  Overall, this dish was pretty good.

text:
Sweating the eggplant, then rinsing/patting dry each slice is a LOT of work.  That alone took me a few hours!  I only used 2 big eggplants, because 3 seemed like too much, and that was plenty!    It does taste really good... not better than Maggiano's, which still has my favorite Eggplant Parmesan.    It's just SO much work for one dish.  I began making this around 7:30 and it wasn't complete until around 10:30.    In sum:  It tastes good, but I'm not sure that it's worth all the hassle (if you follow the suggestions regarding sweating the eggplant and then rinsing/drying each slice with paper towels, which I think you pretty much have to do).

text:
I'm giving this five stars because I'm sure it's delicious as stated, but I did make some changes to make it a bit healthier, and it was soooo good! First, I used egg whites instead of whole eggs. Next, I used a plain bread crumb and oatmeal mixture seasoned with dried Italian herbs (only about 2 cups). I omitted the Parmesan cheese and just used 1 package low-fat mozzarella. I also layered fresh, raw broccoli florets during the baking stage, which added a very nice veg. I'll try using homemade, low-sodium tomato sauce next time. Served it over whole-wheat pasta. DELICIOUS!! I can't wait to eat the leftovers tomorrow!!

text:
Simple, healthy, inexpensive, delicious.  I also sweated the slices as previously described.  I decided not to make the casserole.  Instead, I added the parm cheese to the bread crumbs.  I baked the breaded eggplant on a cookie sheet for about 30 mins turning half way.  Then I served it like chicken parm with sauce and mozzarella cheese on top.  I also added some portabella mushrooms to some store bought sweet basil sauce for a twist.  The eggplant was tender in the middle and crispy on the outside.  Husband rated it 10/10, yummy!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making eggplant parmesan.  Overall, I was very pleased with the results.  I must admit I was alittle nervous at first because the coated eggplant did not brown at all, but I continued as directed. Please not this is default for 10 servings.  I did not realize this until I was half way through, way too much for me.  I had to use a 11X15 pan.  You will definitely need more than two eggs (I used about 5).  The last layer of eggplant I topped with a thin layer of sauce then cheese (recipe didn't specify).  The prep time was well over an hour (mostly prepping eggplant) for me.  To reduce prep timely greatly have atleast two extra large cooking sheets on hand.  This will cut your time in half.  Great taste with no additional seasoning needed!

Oh man this was good.  I did put a few twists on the base recipe but it was great.  I used a couple of food-processored cans of fire roasted tomatoes with around 7 large basil leaves instead of premade sauce.  I also seasoned my own panko breading instead of premade crumbs.  I snuck some zucchini in with the eggplant - yum!  And I also picked up a small nub of a dry italian cheese from my grocer's artisan cheese extras basket.  I guess my point is that you can customize according to what is in your own cupboard.  I served it with a Malbec and it was nice :)

text:
This was great!  I followed suggestions of other reviewers and sweated the eggplant using sea salt for 30 minutes, and then rinsing and patting dry.  I only used one very large eggplant.  I also upped the oven temp to 400 degrees, and baked it for 5 minutes per side.  Then, because of time, I asslembled it as instructed and then microwaved it for 12 minutes on high, turning halfway through.  Served it with pasta and it was a huge hit!

text:
1st time I have made Egg Plant, read the reviews after preparing... should have sweated the egg plant to get rid of the bitter taste. This recipe makes WAYYYY... too many servings! Gave away half and still have leftovers from the other half. 2 Eggs is not enough for 3 Egg Plant and we threw away ALOT of bread crumbs! Also the temp should be more like 400 and 7-10 min on each side. Used vegetable oil spray when the egg plant refused to go brown, next time will coat sheet in olive oil. And cook time will be more like 45 minutes. Didn't want to use dried Basil so used 1/2 cup fresh basil and mixed it with 15oz Ricotta, 2 eggs, mozzarella,and parmesan. Was pretty good the way we made it, husband said if chicken was in it, it would have been the best chicken parmesan he'd ever had. Next time will sweat egg plant.

text:
Great Recipe- I did sweat the eggplant but that added a lot of time and work.  The proportions seemed to be off.  I used one large eggplant.  I needed 3 eggs and 1.5 cups of bread crumbs.  I baked the eggplant at 450 for 7 minutes on each side.  I used two 9x13 pans so I did't have to layer the eggplant.  The eggplant was't mushy at all.

I gave this 3 stars.  If you are looking for a healthy alternative to frying the eggplant, I give it 4 stars.  I sweated the eggplant as suggested, used 1/2 panko crumbs and 1/2 Italian bread crumbs, and boosted the heat (375) and cook time of the breaded eggplant to 10 mins each side.  I was hoping for a "crispier" result.  I do not care for soggy foods and some of the reviews had me concerned. Unfortunalty, it was still soggy.  If your looking for a 5 star recipie, fry the eggplant and serve with your favorite homemade sauce.

This was really good.  I'm a particularly lazy cook, so I put the slices in the oven and forgot about them, so they ended up cooking at least 20 minutes per side.  This actually caused the eggplant slices to be rather crisp, a quality I liked.  I used Classico basil and tomato spaghetti sauce and a can of Hunts fire roasted diced tomatoes. I will definitely make this again.

text:
This recipe was okay... I personally think it tastes better frying the eggplant in olive oil rather than baking it.  It's unhealthier, but mine didn't get crispy like it does when you fry it and that affected the end result of the dish.  It came out mushier than when it's fried first.  It's not a terrible dish, but I just don't see how everyone thinks its so much better than the traditional way.  I also tried breading my eggplant in a gallon-sized plastic bag and while it was cleaner and easier, I don't think it coated the eggplant as well as doing them individually on a plate.  I'm going to stick to my good old-fashioned recipe, even though it's a little unhealthier.  I might try Bobby Flay's version on the Food Network site, if I want to try a different version next time.  The eggplant is fried, too!  Nice attempt, though, at making a traditionally unhealthy dish healthier.

text:
I do not normally care for Eggplant Parmesan, but this was amazing!  I made this dish because my boyfriend requested it for Thanksgiving.  I did not bother measuring out the sauce and cheese, instead I just went by how much I wanted to put on (I ended up using way more than the recipe called for).  I also followed the advice of others and sweated out the eggplant before proceeding with the breading (excellent suggestion), and I baked the breaded eggplant in the oven for about 15 minutes to let them really crisp up - I think that is what makes this recipe.  The eggplant is not totally soggy and bitter, and everyone at my Thanksgiving dinner (even the turkey eaters) really enjoyed it.  This one is a keeper.

text:
This was very tasty.  It is a bit time intensive.  I have always been told (and followed as a rule) that eggplant needs to be drained with salt to get the best out of it.  So I salted and then washed off the eggplant before hand.  I also sliced some zucchini and then followed the same steps as the eggplant.  I found, like many, that the baking time needed to be increased.  Also I found that leaving the whole thing to bake longer was better too.

This was good, although I personally think frying it gets a better flavor (really, what isn't better fried?)  As odd as it sounds, the eggplant flavor is a little too strong when you use this method.   Also, with just two eggplants I went through 5 eggs and three baking sheets worth of slices, cooked them 10 minutes on each side but it wasn't done after 35 minutes in the oven.  I still must not have cut the eggplant thin enough!  So for everyone making the recipe - cut the eggplant very very thinly!

userID:

Display Name:
VeggiePAK
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/280048.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe after reading all the great comments shared by others.  It tasted wonderful!  What a delicious and healthy meal it turned out to be!  As others had shared in their reviews, I "sweated" the eggplant for one hour, then I baked it for 20 minutes on the first side, then 15 minutes on the other side, so it wouldn't burn.  I also dipped the eggplant in flour AFTER the egg and BEFORE the Japanese PANKO bread crumbs I used (both also suggested by another reader).  It made a big difference in the taste.  Added a nice consistency to the dish.  For the pan, I used a 9 x 13 inch pyrex baking dish.  I followed directions except that I used three layers of eggplant, and added Ricotta cheese.  It was light to medium layers of Ragu sauce (a whole 64 oz. jar was used when I was through), prepared  eggplant, organic mozzarella cheese, Ricotta, basil and sauce on top to make three layers of each. It was a great success! I must say that when using the long oriental eggplant, it was very time consuming, but worth it.  It took me four hours from start to putting it in the oven to cook. I will defintely make it again. Now that I have, I can shorten the preparation time. I also think next time I will use marinara sauce instead of traditional tomato sauce.  Thanks to all for the previous reviews!

This was awesome!  I did try to "bleed" the eggplant, but I'm not sure if it made any difference.  I only had table salt, and I simply sprinkled it on the eggplant for about 1/2 hr prior, and actually I forgot to wash it off.  I baked each side about 7 minutes (I did not want it crispy). This was a favorite, and I will definitely recommend it!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was absolutely divine.  I made it using spaghetti sauce that I made myself, which was meatless, not to take away from the eggplant flavour.  I didn't want to use storebought sauce, because what would be the point?  There's too much sodium in those sauces anyway. Make sure you use the best quality Mozzarella you can find because it really makes a difference, since you are using an important amount.  I used 4 small eggplants, and wished I had had more on hand, because it barely covered the sauce.  I didn't use basil because my sauce was already intensely flavoured. I used parsley instead.  I had a hard time browning the bread coating, so after 15 minutes, I switched the oven to broil and it quickly became golden.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:

userID:
2306909
Display Name:
Anne Norman Hastings
isPro:
False
followersCount:
19
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
80
favoritesCount:
242
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1693288.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent - this tasted like Chicken Parm!  I made these changes: I halved the recipe.  Sliced 1/4", then sprinkled with sea salt, let sweat in collander for about an hour.  Rinsed well, then set in water for about 15 minutes.  Patted dry with paper towels. Breaded w/Italian bread crumbs. Put a couple tablespoons of olive oil on a cookie sheet and baked slices at 425 for 7 mins. on each side.  Lowered oven to 350.  Placed slices in a single layer in a 9x13 glass baking dish, homemade tomato sauce on top only (not on bottom), lots of shredded mozzeralla on top of each one, then sprinkled with the Parmesan and a little dried basil.  Baked at 350 for about 35 mins.  Very good!  Reheats just fine in the microwave.

This was an excellent Eggplant Parmesan.  I followed many of the suggestions and cranked the oven up to 450 and baked the slices 7 minutes on each side. Then instead of layering the sauce and cheese, I layered all of the slices in the dish and then covered that with a layer of sauce and then cheese.  Then we sprinkled on fresh basil rather then dried.  Granted we were only using one eggplant, so it wasn't nearly as much.  Had we used the recommended number we probably would have layered.  Still an excellent and yummy dish.

userID:
1714720
Display Name:
Susan Parran

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2449113.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't sweat the eggplant like some do, as I find it turns chewy. I use only Market Basket (neighborhood grocery store) brand marinara. It's inexpensive, all natural, and much, much better tasting than more expensive name brands! One thing I do a little differently is to soak the eggplant slices in Sherry wine before the dip/dredge step. This helps do away with the bitter taste from the seeds. Tip: Don't keep eggplant for longer than two days in the fridge. It doesn't stay firm/fresh very long after purchasing. Also, sprinkle the breadcrumb-dredged slices with about 1/2 cup parmesan cheese before topping with sauce and buffalo mozzerella cheese. This all-natural cheese doesn't contain silicon powder like the pre-shredded packaged cheeses do as an "anti-caking agent."

text:
I made this last night and followed the directions exactly. It was just ok. Even my husband, who usually devours my cooking, asked if we could add some olive oil or butter or something. If you are used to good home made Italian cooking (as we are since I'm Italian), this dish is not very good. It definitely needs some fat. I would definitely suggest drizzling some olive oil over the eggplant before baking them the first time. Frying in a little oil would probably taste the best. After all, most things probably taste better fried. I served this with spaghetti. My homemade sauce and the spaghetti definitely were the highlight of the dish...unfortunately.

None
text:
Wonderful!  I made this for a mom's group lunch where we have one girl who is vegetarian - a big hit with everyone!  From other reviewers suggestions, I also "sweated" out the eggplant with salt first to remove some of the moisture and I used four egg whites instead of the whole egg.  I also cooked eggplant on each side for 10 minutes.  To my breading mixture, I added a couple tablespoons of grated parm cheese and a teaspoon of garlic powder to give it more flavor.  I also used italian seasoning in place of basil.  Highly recommended - a little labor intensive but well worth the effort!

Sept 2012 - our second go at it - didn't do much different from the directions and this was fantastic!  My 8 year old had a great time making dinner for us!

My college-age daughter was home for dinner last night so I decided to finally try this recipe.  Neither of us have had eggplant before so I wasn't too sure what to expect.  I asked a few friends advice on picking a good eggplant since I've never cooked with it, so I am fairly positive I had a good eggplant.  I followed the recipe exactly and when it was done it looked and smelled great.  My daughter absolutely loved it!  Me on the otherhand didn't like it at all.  I am still giving this recipe 5 stars since my daughter enjoyed it so much.  I must just not like the taste of eggplant apparently.  I will make this again for my husband to try.  He has never eaten eggplant either, and I am hoping he has the same opinion as my daughter!

text:
We've made Eggplant Parmesan before and this is exactly how we make it with two changes. 1. To bread the eggplant, we like to dip it in parmesan cheese, then egg, then the bread crumbs. 2. We like to put about a tablespoon or two of EVOO in a pan and brown the eggplant in the EVOO. Then we assemble just as this recipe calls for. It is delicious and a little messy, but wonderful! :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for the first time last night. Nine servings is not realistic. I would say six servings is more accurate, depending on what else you serve along with this. I used 6 baby eggplants, as the regular eggplants did not look very fresh. I did degorge or "sweat" the eggplants for 30 minutes, and I cooked them in a 400 oven for 10 minutes per side. Two jars of basil marinara sauce (Brand: Barilla) were perfect, and this sauce gave the dish a lot more basil flavor than dried basil alone would have. I used the 5-cheese Italian mix rather than plain mozzarella, which really isn't that flavorful on its own. This is a keeper. Thanks for posting!

text:
Fantastic!  My kids (8 & 4 years old)-who keep telling me they don't like eggplant-asked for seconds!  I followed the suggestions of a few other peope, I salted the slices to sweat them for about 30 min.  Then I baked the slices for about 25 min before adding the sauce & cheese.  I think the baking time depends on how thick you make your slices.  I also added garic, oregano, basil & a little salt to Itaian Style breadcrumbs.  My kids tried it after I baked it but before I added the cheese & sauce and they loved it just like that.  Super easy, flavorful & kid approved!

This was a great way to make eggplant without having to fry it!  I followed some of the other suggestions and baked it for longer than suggested.  I baked at 375 for about 9 minutes on each side.  I also coated the pan with olive oil before baking & it gave it a nice golden brown color.  I also sliced the eggplant and coated with sea salt and allowed to sweat for 15 minutes.  Instead of using this eggplant for Eggplant Parm I instead layered it in my lasagna.  Great way to sneak some more veggies into the kids favorite meals!  Thanks for sharing - its a keeper!

I followed the multiple reviews and cooked the eggplant 20 minutes (10 minutes per side).  I mixed up at the grocery store and bought stuffing instead of bread crumbs.  This worked great.  I ended up blending the stuffing in a food processor, and I had my own herbed bread crumbs.

I had much more eggplant than I expected, so I made several stacks of eggplant/followed by sauce/cheese, and basil.  I also added fresh tomato slices each stack. The fresh tomato was a nice addition.   I think this still would have been a 5 without any changes.

text:
One of my favorite foods since I've found this recipe! I do make a few changes. I sweat the eggplant per instructions from other reviewers. I also bake the slices around 8-10 minutes on each side. My first time I made this I didn't slice the eggplant thin enough and it came out very chewy - so I'd definitely recommend slicing the eggplant pretty thinly. I'm also only cooking for two, so I only use 2 eggplants and it's way more than enough. The cheese and sauce and eggplant blend together so deliciously. My mouth is actually watering as I think about it!

text:
Love it love it love it!!!  I always loved eggplant parmesan, this is the first time making it.  It was a hit at our dinner party last week, so I'm making it again for dinner tonight.

The embellishments I made... I use gluten-free breadcrumbs since I'm gluten intolerant (nobody knew the difference!), baked the eggplant pre-saucing for 10 minutes per side, and sliced fresh mozarella to lay across the top as an extra.  I also only use 2 eggplants, and eyeball the sauce so it is more firm rather than runny.
YUMMY!!!

Came out well. my bro is a meat man but really liked it. I followed the advice about weeping the eggplant and I baked them longer than the recipe but still not long enough. next time I will bake them at least 10 minutes on each side. Also one large eggplant was plenty of eggplant for me.

UPDATE: I have made this twice using the trader joe's frozen breaded eggplant. just as good but much easier

text:
This is a great recipe! I am just learning to cook and made this for the first time last night. I chopped up cheese sticks in the food processor to get the mozzarella, which worked really well. Tomato and basil sauce from a jar eliminated the basil, which I didn't have. There were only two of us, so I used 3 little eggplants. At first, I thought I'd have leftovers for days, but that wasn't the case at all! It's nearly gone! The only thing is that I salted the eggplant and no moisture was coming out after 15 minutes, so I rinsed it and continued on with the recipe. I probably wasn't supposed to do that, but I'm impatient! It still was great! I will definitely make this again! I will read up more on if it is really necessary to purge the eggplant or not, before I make this again, though.

Display Name:
Carol Foster

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I started with the basic recipe and will make that again, but wanted to make casserole like Trader Joe's used to sell that had a phyllo crust. I started with 1/2 pkg phyllo dough. Prepared the eggplant as suggested, though only used two and coated the baking sheet with extra virgin olive oil. Melted 1/2 stick butter; generously coated the bottom of a 9x13x2 dish. Put several sheets of phyllo in the bottom, brushed with melted butter, added more dough (total of probably 8 sheets). Placed a layer of eggplant slices on top; made a chiffonade of fresh basil which I sprinkled over the eggplant, added a layer of shredded mozzarella (slices of fresh would be great); then 1/2 jar of a good marinara sauce. Repeated the eggplant, basic, cheese marinara sequence and then added an additional 8 sheets of phyllo dough brushed with butter. Dealing with the phyllo dough is the hardest part of this recipe. Make sure to keep the unused dough covered with a damp towel so it doesn't dry out. Baked for 30 minutes at 350 and it was fabulous. Served with fresh asparagus and a glass of Merlot. I love baking the eggplant as it is a lot less messy and the eggplant doesn't absorb as much oil. Will do my eggplant for all recipes this way from now on.

text:
It does really take about 2 hours, but there is alot of downtime to relax or make a side dish. A hour of that cook time is waiting.  30 minutes for the eggplants to "sweat" and 35 minutes for it to cook.  So its really not that bad and the taste makes it worth the effort.  You dont need 4 cups up breadcrumbs, 2 would probably be just fine.  Do add the parmesan and Italian seasonings to the bread crumbs and a little salt.  Very light dinner, won't weigh you down.

text:
I thought that this was a great recipe.  Neither my husband or I eat eggplant and we both liked it.  This was my first time cooking eggplant.
I did salt it so that it would sweat and was sure to dry it real good.  One eggplant would have been plenty.  I used 2 egg whites and one cup of bread crumb.  I could have used just half cup of bread crumbs and it would have been just right.  I had lots of left over crumbs.  I baked on each side for 10 minutes and they were not as crispy as I would like, so I broiled them for 4 min on each side and they were perfect.  I also baked them on my pizza stone coated with cooking spray and they turned out perfect and crispy.
I used crushed tomatoes instead of sauce to save some calories.  I put the crushed tomatoes on the bottom and then I sauteed chopped bell pepper and onion and missed that with a can of diced tomatoes which I put on top.  I was wanting to add more vegi's and it turned out yummy!  Great recipe.

text:
Very tasty and easy to prepare. For a lower fat/cholecterol recipe I dipped the eggplant slices in rice milk instead of egg. I skipped baking the eggplant slices for 5 minutes on each side because there were too many to fit in my oven at one time. After everything was assembled in the pan I added 1/2 cup rice milk. This gave the recipe enough moisture so the eggplant cooks up nice and soft.

I can only give 4 stars because I used this recipe as a base and modified it a bit.  First I added ricotta cheese, I oven baked the eggplant and then lightly toasted it on the stove, I added oregano, garlic, onion powder and a dash of celery seasoning to it as well.
It turned out delicious with the extra cheese and garlic.  I will definitely be making this recipe again and again!

This was so good and super easy.  I went ahead and baked the eggplant on both sides for 10 minutes b/c that is what several people suggested.  The eggplant was the perfect texture.  Don't know if it made a difference, but because this was just for me, I used only 1 eggplant and eye-balled the ingredient amounts and used fresh chopped basil since I had some on hand. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay.  Eggplant parmesan normally isn't anything special, and this wasn't
an exception (but maybe I'm just not a big fan of this dish in general?).
The preparation is easy, though time consuming.  (Following other
reviewers advice, I (i) "sweated" the eggplant and (ii) in step two, baked 
the eggplant 10 minutes per side, so total time took even longer than in  
the unmodified recipe.)  After a bit of experimentation, I found I enjoyed
it more when I skipped putting spaghetti sauce in the baking dish -that  
made the eggplant a little damper than I'd prefer- but rather added a few 
drops of sauce spread on top of each piece where its flavors ended up
meshing well with the bread crumbs.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I am extremely picky about my eggplant parmesan and literally, before this recipe, there was one place in the world where I would get it (a small Italian restaurant in New York City) where I knew that I would actually like it. Now I have another. 

I scaled this recipe down so that it only called for one eggplant, and my boyfriend made a homemade sauce with fresh tomatoes, mushrooms, basil and a few other spices. I let the eggplants "sweat" for about 10 minutes as other reviewers did and used egg whites instead of a whole egg. 1/4" is the best slicing thickness and anything smaller got a little "extra crispy" as I followed other reviewers' suggestions to bake the eggplant for about 10 minutes on each side. 

This was a GREAT recipe, and one that even my picky boyfriend said that he would have again if I made it again. Thanks!

Display Name:
JUSTCYN

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/228953.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the recipe for eggplant parmesan I was looking for. I used only 1 eggplant and I made this entirely in the microwave. Yep, including "baking" the breaded eggplant slices in a single layer for a 3 1/2 mins. (I had to do 3 pans ). I figured they didn't have to be that crispy since they were going to be baked again in the sauce and cheese. It made the process a lot faster too. After asembling (I forgot the basil but didn't miss it) I baked the pan full and added the mozz. and parmesan on top in the last few mins. Delicious. Oh I did assemble this (except the last cheese ) ahead and refrigerated it until I was ready to bake. Then the baking in the microwave was quick and easy when I was ready. No one will ever notice the eggplant isn't fried! I suspect you could do the work ahead and freeze it like this too. Don't know if it helped but I definetly peeled the eggplant and I did the salt and rinse thing. I did get one comment that it was salty the first night. Didn't notice it the second night--leftovers better than original.

text:
This was really delicious.  The one drawback is that it's very time consuming.  Some previous reviews suggested salting and rinsing the eggplant prior to breading, while others suggested parboiling for a few minutes, so I did both.  I saw no reason to slice my eggplant in rounds, so I sliced lenghthwise for cutlets, which fit better in the pan anyway.  Even with parboiling, I still baked the eggplant for 10 minutes on each side. It browned better with a very light coating of olive oil cooking spray. This would have been even more excellent with a homemade sauce.

text:
I only used 1 eggplant,  so I scaled back the proportions. I also peeled it, salted it, waited 30 minutes, then rinsed and dried each slice. Breaded and baked the slices on a rack for about 25 minutes, at 375. Next time I will use less sauce, and somehow sweeten it up a little (the Traditional sauce was almost bitter). I have never attempted to make Eggplant Parmesan before, and this turned out amazing!

text:
This received a "just OK" review from our young family.  Everyone thought the dish smelled good while it was cooking.   But it was too salty for me, which I attribute to the bread crumbs, plus I have a soy sensitivity so I might try it again if I make my own. But my husband thought it was just OK too and two of my three kids did not like it at all.  The 11YO will normally eat anything and although she liked the taste OK, she does not like the texture of cooked squash so she did not eat her serving.  On the other hand, my normally picky 9 YO absolutely loved it and thought it tasted like pizza. It was a healthy, meatless dish but time consuming to bread the eggplant slices.  Since it was just OK, I would have to look at making some changes before trying it again.

text:
Second time I’m using this recipe. I use stale take and bake  French bread classic breadsticks, which I grate and add powdered garlic and dried oregano. I drizzle a small amount of garlic infused olive oil on the bottom of the pan then begin layering. It’s more delicious days later. Not the quickest prep as the baking of the eggplant takes some time. But once all the eggplant ?? is baked, the assembly is straight forward. I cover the pan with foil, which I remove five minutes before removing the pan from the oven to brown the cheese. Delicious!

text:
I used Japanese eggplants I grew myself and sliced them vertically with a mandoline. It gave me beautiful slices of uniform thickness which I used like lasagna noodles. I didn't have seasoned bread crumbs on hand, so I added Italian seasoning, salt and pepper then followed the recipe as written. When I placed the eggplant slices in the 9"x 13" pan,  I laid the first layer longways and the second layer crossways. I just happened to have a jar of tomato basil spaghetti sauce on hand and it was perfect for this recipe!  I will definitely make this again, especially when we have an abundance of eggplant! My husband is a meat and potatoes kind of guy, but this was so good, I don't think he noticed there was no meat. Score!!

userID:
9957698
Display Name:
atwingnuts
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6178517.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great basic recipe for "baking" instead of traditional frying. 
I took the advice of other reviews & salted the thin slices of eggplant leaving them to rest for half an hour, then rinsing & patting dry. I've never done this before & I believe the exceptional flavor & texture was enhanced by doing that. I also flipped the slices several times, on the parchment paper lined pan, to get the crispness & cook that I preferred. 
I stacked my eggplant layers with a dollop of tomato sauce, mozzarella, grated parmesan AND cottage cheese.
Fresh basil from the garden atop as well.
This was a very fragrant & light eggplant parmesan compared to the more common fried heavier versions. I believe I will be using this baking method from now on...

5

This was incredible! I made it for my husband, mom, and her husband and they could not stop talking about how amazing it was the whole time they were eating, and even the next morning. My mom said it was the best Eggplant Parmesan she has ever had and her husband said it may just be his new favorite dish. 
I used Prego Marinara sauce, and put a little Tony's Creole seasoning in between the layers and Italian seasoning on top instead of basil. And I did more parmesan cheese than it asked for because, well, parmesan cheese :)
I will definitely be making this again.

text:
I used Appel Foods nut crumbs Spicy for my breadcrumbs because im on a Keto diet. I sprayed my slices with olive oil after dipping them in egg and the nut crumbs. Also, since I was soooo hungry i totally skipped the salting part. Guess what!! Not bitter, not salty, and perfectly cooked. I first browned them for 15 min total and then spread with a mixture of ricotta and mozzarella then pizza sauce. I sprinkled with parmesan cheese and covered with foil. Cooked at 350 for 50 min. Perfectly cooked. I love this recipe.
