https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Before I make this, I slice the eggplant and put the slices on paper towels.  Salt it on one side and let it sit for 5-10 minutes.  The acid will bubble to the top.  Wipe the slices off, turn them over and repeat the process.  This removes the acid that irritates the inside of some people’s mouth.  Then proceed with the recipe.
Review:

5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the BEST eggplant recipe ever.  I am dairy free so I don't use any cheese.  I just layer with eggplant and sauce.  In my opinion you don't need the cheese, it's that good.  I don't sweat my eggplant, no idea why people do that?  I use three large eggplants and make a large pan and smaller one.  You only need 2 1/2 cups of breadcrumbs and way more than 2 eggs for breading.  I think I use 5-6.  You also need to bake the eggplant  for 10 minutes on each side. Cut your eggplant very thin and it will come out so much better.

I made this but I'm on a low carb diet so  dipped my eggplant in 2/3 almond flour, 1/2 cup of Parmesan cheese, and 1/2 cup of  of Italian bread crumbs. Used 1/3 cup of grated Parmesan cheese and 12 oz of mozzarella because that's all I had.  It tasted amazing.

userID:
642074
Display Name:
CHARLEYGIRL1215
isPro:

6

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I listened to other reviews and sprinkled salt on both sides of the eggplant and laid them on paper towels, flipping, and blotting them for an hour.  ALOT of water came out!  After I dipped in egg and breadcrumbs,  I put them in the oven for 10 min, then flipped them and ut them back in for another 10.  While they were in the oven, I also put thinly sliced onion on a cooking sheet and roasted it as well. (onion roasted for 20 min.  I didnt turn it)  
After it came out, I poured a jar of Prego in a 9x13, put one layer of the eggplant on top, THEN I laid all the roasted onion slices on top of the eggplant, THEN a layer of sliced fresh mushrooms, THEN a can of drained whole plum tomatoes.  Sprinkled a bag of mozzerella cheese on top of the plum tomatoes, then laid another layer of eggplant, then a jar of sauce,  a little mozzerella, and parmesan cheese and I sprinkled dried basil, a little garlic powder, italian seasonings on top.  Covered the whole top in foil and baked for an hour at 350.  MY WHOLE FAMILY LOVED THIS!  It is amazing!

userID:
3762499
Display Name:
Mare
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1074495.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very Good recipe.  Time consuming but worth it.  My family does not like the bitterness of eggplant, so I peeled and sliced my eggplant, coated in salt, placed in a colander and covered with a very wet paper towel to "sweat out" the bitterness for 15 minutes.  Then thoroughly rinsed and patted dry before putting in the beaten eggs.  I used Panko breadcrumbs, Italian seasonings and parmesan cheese mixed together for the dry mix.  Then baked at 450 degrees at 7 minutes on each side.  Placed in baking dish with sauce and mozzarella cheese and baked again at 450 degrees for 17 minutes.  I found these suggestions and my alterations helped a lot.  Thank you for the recipe!!

I used this recipe to make eggplant Parmesan for the first time and I thought it was great! The only thing I would change is the baking time of the breadcrumb-coated eggplant slices; 5 minutes per side was definitely not enough to get them crispy.

city:

country:
None
text:
Turned out amazingly well.  Everyone loved the flavor of the breading.  Only modification is that after I sliced the eggplant, I  generously salted (course kosher salt) both sides and rested it in a colander for about 40 minutes.  This process helps pull out some of the water from the eggplant and bitterness.  I rested the eggplant on paper towels and then placed another layer of paper towels on top to pull out more water.  I put a cast iron on top of the eggplant slices for added pressure.  After this, I followed the directions accordingly.  I did add shredded pecorino romano to the mozzarella, which added a nice flavor for the topping.

userID:
4976982
Display Name:
lutzflcat
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5754
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2815
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6445679.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
1.29.18  I sweated the eggplant slices just as many other reviewers have done.  Salted the slices, placed them on a rack over a foil-lined cookie sheet, and let them sit for 30 minutes.  I then put the slices into my water-filled salad spinner, spun for about five times to remove the salt, drained the water, and then gave it a really good spin which got the eggplant pretty dry.  After breading, they went back onto the same rack, and into the oven for about 25 minutes.  Since both sides of the slices were exposed to the heat, there was no need to flip halfway through, both sides crisped up nicely.  I checked for doneness, they were just slightly undercooked and a light brown, so then I assembled the casserole. Honestly, I didn’t measure anything, just eyeballed quantities.  Would recommend that you use a spaghetti sauce that you really like because that definitely will be what you taste the most.  I used a jar of Priano Spicy Garlic Arrabbiata Pasta Sauce from Aldi which has lots of flavor and just a little kick.  I love eggplant parmesan, but have never before made it, but I certainly will be making this again.

text:
This was my first time making it, and it didn't work out.  The eggplant was WAY undercooked.  The recipe is also a bit vague - how thin is thinly sliced?  How many slices should you have, even approximately?  Three eggplants seemed like a lot (I had leftovers compared to the amount of sauce & cheese and room in my pan.  After baking the eggplant, should it be golden brown?  Mine was not - really didn't cook at all - what was the point?  The flavor was good, but it was barely edible.  I'm not sure why the reviews are so high  . . .   I see others (in hindsight) gave it 5 starts, but altered the recipe by either frying the eggplant (defeating the point) or raising the oven temp and/or cooking time.

This recipe is delicious.  My husband who is a picky eater ate two large helpings.    I used parchment paper on my cookie sheet as was suggested and it was perfect and did not stick.    I was so glad to find a recipe that you did not have to fry the  egg plant in oil. That is not necessary at all.    I left it in the oven for 10 minutes and then turned it for another 13 minutes. sized  down the other ingredients to match up with that  and making two layers in my 9x9 casserole dish.  Perfect!!

text:
This is a very good recipe, especially for vegetarian guests. Three eggplants are way too much.  I used two and had lots of eggplant leftover.  Also, it is important to rinse off the salt after draining the eggplant.  Next time I will use a four cheese combo instead of the mozzerella and parmesan.  It should be tastier.  The recipe is easy but still takes time to do all the steps. And the eggplant needs 15- 20 minutes of baking prior to the layering process.

I do encourage you to whip up a quick batch of marinara. Saute an onion and some garlic then add 2 cans crushed tomatoes and a bit of salt and cook down. thats it! everyone loves it and it couldnt be easier.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4054763.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's great to find a healthier recipe than my usual eggplant parmesan.  Don't get me wrong...my family and I love my standard one with the fried breaded eggplant, but we don't need all that oil!  Plus, it's wonderful to save time by not having to fry each slice of eggplant.  Baking the slices instead really helps lessen the time spent on an already labor-intensive dish.  Another bonus...less messy clean-up.

I have to say though that when I took the baked slices out of the oven, they did not look or smell nearly as tempting to eat some right away (like the lightly pan-fried ones do).  But I ate one anyway,  just to compare.  Gotta say, it wasn't the "OMG, this is sooooo good" experience that I have with my old recipe.  

I wouldn't bake the eggplant slices again if I were going to use them in a more naked recipe, BUT in the finished eggplant parmesan, it was hard to tell the difference.  Maybe not quite as tender, but for the "just noticeable difference" it makes, this recipe is soooooo much healthier and saves so much time!  I will definitely make it again and maybe not tell anyone which way I cooked it!

text:
Dolores is "right on" with this recipe! I have baked my eggplant slices for years. My variation slices them about 1/4 to 3/8 thick and I add some parmesan ( dry grated) to my crumbs. Bake at 400, turning once, until they start to brown. Maybe 10 - 15 minutes. Then continue with the layered casserole.
    I like to make sure a few of those slices don't fit into the casserole and just eat them on the side!!!

text:
This high rating is because it was so clear and straightforward and seemed to have rave reviews from many. I wanted a no-hassle recipe because my eggplant was old from holding in fridge a bit too long and the skin had lost its deep purple color. Was it still salvageable?   I did not want to waste it or try something exotic with it so I went ahead with prepping late at night.  After slicing and peeling and tasting raw the eggplant still seemed fine. The simplicity of this recipe inspired me to go ahead and make it into a parmesan. 

The breading & baking worked great. Modifications included coating my ancient baking pan with a light coat of olive oil, chopping a Spanish onion, browned and added to the canned sauce sauce, and using fresh mozzarella.  It looked great coming from the oven and a corner test indicated it tasted as good as it looked. I will refrigerate the casserole dish and reheat-bake tomorrow.

The recipe is great, as it is, but I am following a low carb-low cal diet, so I had to make some changes.  I baked the eggplant slices both sides (sprayed with pam, garlic salt and pepper) and layered them with tomato sauce, mozzarella and parmesan, finishing with parmesan. This was my very first time cooking with eggplant. I was drawn to this recipe because it was no-fry and highly rated. I planned to use homemade meat sauce and fresh mozzarella, so the eggplant was the only true wildcard. I used this recipe as a guide, rather than following it exactly. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really good, but a very time-consuming pain to make (hence only 4 stars). Notes to self for next time (because there NEEDS to be a next time!):
1.) Only use the egg-shaped eggplant, not the long snake-like kind. Bigger slices mean less dipping time and less hassle.
2.) Make sure your bread crumbs are FINE and DRY. It would be worth buying the store-bought kind for this. Otherwise, the egg mixture comes off on them, and they end up gooey, and the eggplant slices don't get breaded.
3.) You'll need at least 4 eggs.
4.) Don't skimp on the sauce.
5.) Make an extra-big batch and freeze some so you can get two meals out  of not much more work.
Review:

text:
This was excellent!!!  My husband and daughter say that this is a keeper.  
After reading some comments I did sweat the eggplant for 30 minutes.  To make this a little bit more healthier (husband has diabetes) I used ground almonds and Italian seasonings instead of bread crumbs.
I tried the  "shake n bake" method, unfortunately the almond meal absorbed a lot of moisture and would not coat all of the eggplant slices after a while, so I may try to dredge it next time and see if it coats better that way? 
This is now a family favorite, thank you so much for the recipe.

I followed the recipe but did sweat the eggplant slices for about 30 minutes,then rinsed  the excess salt off with cold tap water and dried them with paper towels. I also used my homemade sauce. This was the first time I tried baking the eggplant instead of frying it and was very satisfied with the way it tasted. I served this with fettuccine pasta tossed in a light garlic butter and topped with more of my homemade sauce, sprinkled some chopped parsley over the top for some "green" and crusty bread. I'll make this again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I baked the eggplant slices for 10 min on each side at 350 and then baked the assembled dish for the suggested 35 min at 350. This left the eggplant with the exact right amount of firmness. I think only baking 5 min on each side would leave it a bit too firm. I sprayed some oil on the pans before baking the eggplant, which helped it a bit with browning. I did not peel the eggplant or let sit with salt. (I just don't find the taste of eggplant bitter, salt or no salt.) The next time I make it, I'll spend some time on the sauce. I think a tomato sauce heavy on garlic and basil would be a nice complement.

dateLastModified:

userID:
15869531
Display Name:
Antoinette
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
11
favoritesCount:
122
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe! This was my first time cooking with eggplant and it turned out wonderfully! As previous reviewers suggested, I did not peel the eggplant, but salted the 1/4 inch slices and let sit in a colander in my sink for 30 minutes first. I didn't have sea salt so I used regular salt instead. After rinsing and patting the eggplant dry with paper towels, I seasoned them lightly with salt, pepper, garlic power, and onion powder before dipping them in egg followed by Italian breadcrumbs. I lined a cookie sheet with foil and sprayed a coat of Pam on top before placing the eggplant slices on top. I set the oven to 425 and cooked them for about 13 minutes each side. Once finished, I layered the bottom of a Pyrex dish as indicated in the recipe using Classico traditional sauce, eggplant, and Kraft Italian five cheese blend (Parmesan, mozzarella, provolone, Asiago, and Romano). For the top, I layered eggplant, sauce, then topped everything off with cheese and baked at 425 for 20 minutes. 1 eggplant made about 3 servings. I can't wait to cook this for friends!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A great basic for me.  Removing the brown, bitter taste from the eggplant is truly necessary.  I've tried it without salting and the bitterness does come through a bit, but enough to notice. I use organic multigrain bread crumbs and add my own seasonings - dried garlic, and pepper. I added dried basil, garlic, parsley and a wonderful spice called mushroom truffle mix to the egg mixture, let the spices open up before dipping the eggplant. By lightly spraying olive oil into a large nonstick pan took much less time than baking. I shake off excess breeding and follow this recipe. It turns out perfect. Laying the eggplant, sauce and cheese on organic spinach linguine sealed this as a go to for any occasion.

text:
Awesome recipe!  Made a smaller batch for two. 1 eggplant, 1 cup bread crumbs, 1/2 cup of grated asiago or parm cheese,  fresh parsley, 1/2 teas garlic powder, pepper, dash season salt.  2 eggs.  Sliced, dipped, baked 7 min each side on a evoo jelly roll pan. Removed from pan, Cooled. Used Bertoli organic tomato basil sauce. Reheated 350 covered 35 min topped with sliced fresh mozzerella. Broiled 5 min. Served over Angel hair.

text:
I did make several changes and yes, I will definitely make it again. Since there are only 2 of us, 1 eggplant sufficed as an entree. Therefore, I cut the recipe by 2/3. Since we also must watch sodium intake, I used (and always use) Panko breadcrumbs; they served us well in this recipe. The brand of Panko I use has 110 calories and 35 mg. of sodium in 1/2 cup. I also used a pasta sauce with only 120 mg. of sodium in 1/4 cup. We found no loss of flavor. Great recipe! Thank you. I forgot to add I baked this in my dual convection oven at 350 for 25 minutes, checked the eggplant and it was perfectly cooked.

The end result was good but the recipe was not accurate. It took me at least an hour to prep the meal, not 25 minutes as stated. There's no way that skinning, breading and baking the eggplant and then combining the marinara sauce and cheese takes only 25 minutes.  Also it recommends using 3 eggplants which would have required an additional 9x13 pan. 

Overall I give this four stars because it tasted good but it definitely took longer than expected.

Getting the saltiness right is a little tricky.  If you do not rinse the salt off of the eggplant slices prior to cooking, the dish can be too salty.  Wiping the slices with a paper towel is insufficient.
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2016-09-14T08:56:56.3
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
8662480
Display Name:
judy2304
isPro:
False
followersCount:
25
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
187
favoritesCount:
508
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/871418.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cooked this dish tonight for dinner, but I started it last night, and I am so glad that I did. I used 3 medium sized eggplants (which is relative as to size). I took me a couple of hours to peel, slice, bread, and bake the eggplant. I did sprinkle each slice with salt, and let them sweat for 30 minutes. Then I laid them out in batches on paper towels and used another paper towel on top to absorb moisture. In batches, I dipped in egg and breaded, and laid them on the baking sheets. For the medium eggplants, I needed two large  baking sheets that are 20" x 15". So each baking sheet used a rack in my oven. I was concerned that baking two levels wouldn't bake them evenly. So I baked them separately at about 10 minutes per side. After they cooled, I put them in a zip-lock baggie for construction of the dish the next day.  For the breading, I needed 4 eggs and closer to 5 cups of breading crumbs. 

Tonight, I layered the spaghetti sauce ( 2 jars of Ragu), grated Parmesan, and mozzarella as described, but I used more Parmesan and mozzarella than called for in the recipe. I just used what was needed for each layer. All of the eggplant slices fit into a 9" x 13" casserole. Baking for 40 minutes at 350 degrees, the casserole was only 89 degrees. So I increased the temperature to 375 degrees and baked for an additional 15 minutes. At this point, the casserole was browned and at 120 degrees. Personally, I didn't care for it, but maybe I just don't care for eggplant Parmesan.
Review:
Rating:
1
dateLastModified:
2016-09-14T07:24:16.003
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
20343948
Display Name:
Merle
isPro:

I make this but slice my egg plant super thin and fry it.  Then I layer it with mozzarella cheese and dabs of ricotta cheese and more mozzarella.  I make my own home made marinara sauce I never use jar sauce.  I layer it like lasagna and bake it in the oven till its heated up.  My husband hated eggplant till he tried mine. The trick is slice it thin and change the oil when you are frying it.

text:
Outstanding. This will now be my "go to" recipe for Eggplant Parm after many years and many different recipes. The ricotta is the key!
I will admit I cheated a bit. I used frozen breaded eggplant! One of the reasons I don't make this dish more often is because of the time and effort it takes to prepare the eggplant. While I prefer using fresh when possible, I found that this simple change will make it much easier to have this more often! I couldn't tell the difference in the completed dish.
I also used my best friend's recipe for the sauce. She comes from a long, long line of Italian cooks and this sauce made this wonderful dish even more special!

userID:
1060346
Display Name:
Thisni Caza
isPro:
False
followersCount:
30
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
412
favoritesCount:
891
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/843945.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made one-third recipe in a 7"X 11" baking dish, using one eggplant. Flavor was good, but I made changes as suggested in numerous reviews: sweated the eggplant slices, rinsed, patted dry; used ww homemade breadcrumbs seasoned with garlic, oregano, paprika, salt, and pepper; dredged the slices in flour, then egg, then crumbs; baked at 375 for twenty minutes on a rack without turning. After I placed the slices on the rack, I sprayed them with vegetable oil spray to facilitate crispness. Plan ahead? Discovered that I didn't have spaghetti *or* jarred marinara = / ... so threw a sauce together and used rigatoni.  I haven't made eggplant or chicken parm, so can't speak to the traditional recipe, but what I like is the crispy with the sauce and cheese, which won't happen with layering the slices in sauce. I sprayed the baking dish with vegetable oil spray, added a single layer of pasta, covered the pasta with sauce, placed the eggplant slices atop, put just a teaspoon of sauce on each slice, then sprinkled each slice with Italian blend cheese. Baked at 375 until bubbly, then turned to broil for a couple of minutes. Next time...just personal preference...I think I'll just assemble everything at serving so that the eggplant remains crispy. I may even increase the temp for baking the eggplant. I think a lower temp takes longer to crisp at the risk of over-baking the eggplant. Oh...and I prepped the eggplant in the morning. After rinsing and patting dry, stored in the frig layered with

country:
None
text:
This takes longer but worth doing. I got this from another reviewer.
 5 stars. Baking the eggplant instead of frying does not take away from the flavor of the dish one bit. Also, I chose to sweat the eggplant before breading by peeling, slicing, sprinkling with sea salt and placing in a collander in the sink for about 30 minutes. This pulls out any bitterness. Just be sure to rinse it well with water and pat dry with paper towels before breading. I did two layers of eggplant. You can layer however you like, you just to be sure the top layer of eggplant is topped with sauce and then cheese. I would also add 2 fresh garlic  next time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Have made this 3 times now in 3 weeks! Everyone loves it & likes that the eggplant isn't fried.  This is a great recipe & has been well received by a diverse group of people.   I did make minor changes , most were related to only wanting a 9" square panful.  I used one large Italian eggplant and adjusted the measurements for everything else by eyeballing it. I don't think you need to measure precisely for this.  I used Italian breadcrumbs and added some garlic powder, oregano and freshly ground black pepper.  I did find that I needed to bake the breaded eggplant for about 50% longer than suggested.(.at least 8 minutes per side).  I did two layers of eggplant/cheeses /sauce combo.  I also baked first 20 minutes with aluminum foil covering the pan, then removed for the balance of baking time. They cheese still got nice and melty and thick /chewy without being burned. Definitely a keeper!!

country:
None
text:
OK, first off, pretty yummy recipe! Never had eggplant before and was looking for a semi-healthy recipe, thanks! I did make a few tweeks though, first, I only used 2 eggplants to feed 4 of us, and there were leftovers! I salted each slice and let it sit for about twenty minutes before rinsing in cold water, as per another suggestion, and then found that 2 1/2 cups of breads crumbs and two eggs sans yolks were plenty to cover all the eggplant slices and then some... I did choose to use Gluten Free garlic crumbs for a kick and then just the egg whites. Finally, I cooked the slices for 10 minutes a side, like someone else suggested for more crunchiness, and it worked.  This was very good and will definitely be made again!!

text:
This was really simple and so good! I actually fried the eggplant before baking thinking it would be extra crispy, but it was totally unnecessary and I won't do it in the future. Definitely recommend a quick homemade sauce over jarred sauce - I think it works better to complement the flavor of the eggplant without overpowering. I also used fresh mozzarella instead of the packaged shredded kind and I think it made a huge difference. Not much more expensive either.

country:

text:
First of all it's an awesome recipe.  I picked up 2 eggplants at our farmers market,  and there is no way I could have used 3 eggplants, except maybe the little scronny ones they have at the grocers.  I loved the baked part of putting the dipped and panko'd eggplant in the oven.  I have my oven at exactly 350 degree's and it took longer than 5 minutes to brown each side.  I would just keep an eye on your time frame.  I did not use any basil, because I forgot.  I was in a time crunch so I used canned Hunts Spaghetti sauce.  I went through two large cans and probably could have used 3.  I used a mixture of the cheeses I picked up at a large grocery chain.  The cheese contained an "Italian mix" of cheeses.  I used two 8 oz. packages.   It was a very very good recipe and everyone who got some loved it.

text:
I've been on a spree to try out new and varied veggies with my family and, in that vein, I decided to try this recipe after reviewing this and several other eggplant recipes on this site. Now that I've made it, I must say that the end product is delicious and I recommend it to anyone and *especially* if you like eggplant. My wife, who detests eggplant, even ate and said that it was pretty good the second day (we liked it even better as leftovers the second day).

My two girls wouldn't touch it, unfortunately. They view all kinds of veggies with suspicion and I think that it carried over to this. That, coupled with my wife telling them how bad eggplant was really did this recipe in for them.

Excluding the personal drama at home, I definitely recommend this recipe. The eggplant came out perfect after baking and I could have eaten it up right then. Adding in the sauce and cheese just made it all that much better. I'm giving it 3 stars because of how the rest of the family took to it but if I were rating it based solely on my experience I'd give it 4.5.

This dish is really good!  I didn't have some of the ingredients needed, so I used what I had.  I had a shake n' bake bread crumbs that was parmesan crusted flavor and I didn't have mozzarella cheese, but I had fiesta blend of shredded cheese (shredded Monterey jack, cheddar, queso quesadilla & asadero cheese) and grated parmesan.  Oh, and no eggs, either.  I did bake the eggplant slices for 10 minutes on each side, since it seems everybody else pretty much prefers to do that, too.  So, all and all, still very delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is an excellent starting point for your family's new favorite dish! One large male eggplant was enough for DH and me to have second helpings for dinner as well as lunch the next day. I skipped salting/boiling, layered the breaded slices with parm. cheese EVERY level and used very little sauce (1/4 cup marinara) and moz. to avoid sogginess. Following other posters I baked the casserole in a hot oven (400) for approx. 25 minutes plus for a drier crispy top and tender but not mushy center (personal taste preference). We were out of bread crumbs so I crushed up plain croutons and added Italian seasoning to taste-- delicious! Served over spaghetti (with extra marinara to taste). Delicious left overs!!! In the future I'll  make full recipe and freeze half.

text:
I used authentic Italian sauce, and next time I would only use one large eggplant and a smaller dish.  Also, use a slicer to cut the eggplant in thin slices. The ones I cut by hand were too thick and, as this was our first attempt at having eggplant in anything (ever), I didn't realize how gross the thicker portions would be.  I tried to cut down on prep time with the thicker pieces and really regretted it.  If I had behaved it would've been phenomenal. Everyone loved the flavor.   Followed recipe, except for my poor decision in slicing.

text:
OMG this recipe was unbelievable!!  I took it to Christmas dinner and it was a HUGE success.  The biggest sign for me that this is a great recipe that I will continue to make in the future...the kids loved it!!!  I thought for sure they would stay away from it, but all 3 kids at the family dinner tried it, ate it, and LOVED IT!!!!  I followed some of the previous reviewers suggestions and it came out phenomenal! (I sweat the eggplant for 30mins, I didn't have enough time to do it for any longer than that but still came out great; I also baked for 7 mins on each side).  I used egg whites only and Panko crumbs (love the crispy texture more than regular bread crumbs).  Next time I will use flour on each piece of eggplant before putting it in the wash, but otherwise, this was a fantastic recipe!!

text:
I loved this! Seriously awesome. I always thought I hated eggplant but I was so wrong. The finished meal was delicious but apparently eggplant isn't supposed to be chewy although I didn't mind that, better than overcooked and soggy really, (I'm reading reviews here after the fact) so perhaps I will bake the eggplant like 7 minutes per side at a higher temp like other reviewers suggested. (I did the first bake 10 minutes like the video suggested and 25 minutes for the assembled meal since I only cooked one eggplant instead of 3.) Anyway you slice it, it was good. I also added FRESH basil which I think makes a difference and smells divine when cooking. Thank you Doery!

None
text:
Liked the no fry version. Gave only 3 stars because it needed to be tweaked. Otherwise th taste basically depends on your sauce and quality of cheeses. 1. Bake eggplant slices until fairly soft or else they will end up chewy in your final dish. 2. Make sure your sauce is on the liquid side to give needed juice to the dish when baking. 3. Cover the dish with foil while baking to keep it from drying out and remove last few minutes for cheese to brown and bubble. I actually drizzled some olive oil over the top as the whole thing was just too dry. Know what to do next time now.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe is good, but I agree with some of the suggestions made in other reviews. I used a rosa blanca eggplant, so I didn't need to peel or sweat the slices, but I did bake them longer--almost 20 minutes. Also, given the bumper crop of tomatoes and zucchini we have right now, I made a chunky tomato sauce with coarsely chopped onions, red and yellow peppers, zucchini, celery and lots of garlic. In addition, I had some grilled portobello mushroom caps left over from a barbecue and I layered those with the eggplant slices. It makes it a vegetarian feast and worth it if you have the extra time.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'll try this again. I'd never cooked with eggplant and didn't know what to expect but it turned out pretty good - even my 4 apprehensive kids ate it. I used 1 very large eggplant and it filled two baking sheets. It was enough to do two layers in the 9x13 pan and have some leftover. Before breading, I salted and sweat it. Because I had two pans I did convection at 375 for 10 mins on each side. They were a great texture. Then I did 350 with sauce and cheese. The meal overall took awhile to prepare, but for a veggie meal on a night you have time, go for it.

text:
Very good recipe!  This is my first time trying eggplant and this seemed a pretty good/traditional way to try it out.  Breading and baking all the eggplant slices seemed like a lot of work, although probaably worth it.  Next time I may try just soaking it all in egg/milk mixture in a bowel and then shaking it all at once (or twice) in a ziplock bag with the breadcrumbs, and bake for ten minutes without turining.  Taste was very good although some of the eggplant seems a little bitter.  I think someone suggested peeling a little deeper or soaking in saltwater.  May be a good suggestion.

Healthy and delicious Italian dinner! I made a couple changes though as I only cook for myself and my boyfriend. Instead of regular bread crumbs I used panko, seems to make the breading hardier, which I like.I also only used half the recipr. Finally, instead of cooking in a casserole dish with sauce I simply put a spoonful of sauce and low-fat cheese on top of each cutlet after it had been cooked. I then popped it back into the oven to heat the sauce and melt the cheese. They came out wonderful and crisp!

text:
Absolutely delicious. Just one note that I might add to the recipe: thickness of the eggplant slices! Eggplant size/weight also might help. I bought two and did not realize they were gigantic compared to the standard eggplant. I also sliced them really thin (1/8-1/4 inch), so I was breading for a long time. 5 eggs and 3 cups of seasoned bread crumbs later, I had too much eggplant to even fit in the dish, so I have a whole packet of breaded medallions to freeze. This recipe was a bit time consuming, but I would definitely make it again.

text:
This was as good as any nice italian restaurant! I did follow other reviewer's suggestions and put the eggplant out for about 30 minutes with sea salt to "sweat" it and it really helped to make the eggplant crispy instead of soggy. I followed the recipe exactly other than adding a little extra on the parmesan cheese. I also think the sauce you use is key to good flavor....you have to love it. I used a meat sauce out of the jar called Mid's. Delicious! Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
Delicious! I used homemade sauce and this was so good. The only change I made was not peeling the eggplant. I also didn't salt the eggplant before baking it, I like the flavor of eggplant. Oh, and I baked the slices for 10 minutes on each side at 400, then lowered the temp to 350 and baked for an additional 20 or so minutes. Addition: I've tried this several different ways, and it's really good as written, but when I broiled on low for 8 minutes per side and didn't bake with sauce it was much crispier. Just topping with heated sauce was good enough. Baking it really isn't that necessary.

text:
We LOVE this recipe and it is now my 9 y/o daughter's favorite meal.  I use olive oil cooking spray on the baking sheets and then give a light spray on top of the breaded slices.  We live at high altitude so I end up cooking these at least 15 min. each side, a little bit crispy.  Since there are just 3 of us, I usually use one eggplant, add choppped spinach to the sauce (more vitamins!), and use an 8x8 pan.  IF I have excess eggplant slices, we store them in the fridge and eat as a snack by warming up and dipping in sauce.  THANK YOU for this no-fry recipe!!

text:
Very delicious, kind of reminded me of a low carb lasagna! I used my bf's awesome, homemade recipe for the spaghetti sauce (which I added sliced mushrooms to). I used a pre-grated Italian cheese mix that had parmesan, romano and other Italian cheeses. Before making I read in some of the reviews that it tasted a bit bland. I'm guessing that is probably due to the kind of spaghetti sauce that they used since that is obviously the main flavor in the recipe. Our eggplant parmesan was far from bland. The one thing that I would probably do next time is to use a peeler to take the skin off the eggplant since the skin made it a bit too chewy for my liking. I would also make sure to cut the eggplant slices thinner.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I was very hesitant to try eggplant, but with this recipe I'm sure I'll be having it again.  This was a delicious dish.  I changed a few things according to other reviews.  I only used one eggplant (medium/large) and it would have fed 6 people, 2 cups of bread crumbs (could have probably used only 1 1/2) and omitted the parmesan cheese (to save calories).  I also did not peel the eggplant (mom always said to eat the skins - there's where the nutrients are) and I ended up having to bake the 1/4" - 1/2" slices about 15 minutes per side.  Some say salting it will help diminish the bitterness, but what I've read is if the eggplant is bitter, then it was overripe. Was a great dish and will definitely be making it again.  Goes great following a side salad!

I normally LOVE a good eggplant parmesan but this recipe was disappointing. 3 eggplants is WAY too much, I think 1 or 2 at the most would have been better. text:
This recipe is very easy and we really enjoyed it. The only thing I would point out is that it's more like 2 cups of bread crumbs and 4 eggs. I only used 2 large eggplants but the egg kept running out. Also by salting my eggplant it kept them firm and took out all the bitter juice that will sit in a larger eggplant while it cooks. But otherwise the recipe was great!

text:
I have had the recipe saved for ages and was excited to try it out. It was my first time cooking with eggplant, so I heeded the advice of other reviewers and salted the eggplant for 20 minutes prior to breading and baking. I baked the slices for 15 minutes one each side and another 30 minutes once assembled. The eggplant was not cooked enough (perhaps I sliced it too thick?) and the flavor was really disappointing.  In hindsight, I should have halved the recipe.    I'm giving this recipe 2 stars because I must have done something wrong along the way, clearly 1,000 other reviewers loved it.

text:
Yum!! I'm always looking for tasty and filling vegetarian meals... and this is it! I did prepare it a little differently because I was only working with one eggplant. I increased the bake time and temp to 10 min per side at 400. And instead of putting everything together in a baking dish, I just made individual rounds. Kept the eggplant on the baking sheet, topped each with a good amount of sauce, and a slice of fresh mozzarella. Then back in the oven for a few min to melt the cheese. They looked pretty and tasted amazing!!

text:
This tasted pretty good, my only problem is that it took a lot of dishes to bake all that eggplant (I gave up after loading a 9x13 & an 8x8..didn't want to dirty tons of dishes) So I ended up using less eggplant than needed, and it wasn't as filling as it would have been if I could have gotten all the eggplant into it. It tasted great though! So, next time I'll just have to use more pans so I get the full 3 eggplants in there (I used 2)  Also I used Ener-g egg replacer instead of eggs, since I didn't have any. Usually it ends up just fine, but I had to use twice the amount of mix, for less eggplant.

text:
Easy, cheap, good!  I didn't have italian seasoned bread crumbs so I made my own w/ some plain + italian seasoning + garlic + parm then I mixed in some panko bread crumbs for extra crunch.  It was super good and made my tiny apartment smell soooooo good.  I hope it made my entire floor hungry!  I used Culinary Circle's Florentine Style Pasta Sauce and it was perfect.  I did not salt the eggplant or whatever others suggested (I don't have time for it and I don't want the extra salt) it came out perfect w/o it since I seasoned the bread crumbs well.  I also chose to keep the skin on and prefer it that way.

text:
Very nice recipe. You do need to bake the eggplant longer than indicated. Take the time to drain the eggplant by sprinkling it with salt, letting it sit for 20 minutes, and then rinsing it before baking. I served it with rigatoni on the side and had plenty of leftovers.  Nice change from meat.

text:
Excellent directions for Eggplant Parmesan! I took the suggestion of some other reviewers and "bled" the eggplant for around 20min in some sea salt. I did have to bake the eggplant for 10-15 minutes per side to get it the right color. I prepared a ricotta cheese mix with parmesan, 1 egg and some seasonings and added that to the layers. This turned out very well for me with the aforementioned alterations; I couldn't tell the eggplant wasn't fried!

text:
Pretty good recipe. However, I had trouble with the eggplant crisping in the oven. I took it out after 7-8 minutes and poured olive oil on the baking sheet and baked it for about 7 minutes each side @ 450. It finally browned up after using the oil. Also, I sweated the eggplant. Even though I rinsed afterwards, apparently there was still a good amount of salt which made the whole dish a bit on the salty side (maybe I used to much salt in the sweating process). I might just lightly pan fry them next time and then stick them in the oven with the sauce and cheese.

text:
I was pleasantly surprised at how well this turned out. I never have much luck with eggplant.  One thing I changed was I did not peel the eggplant.  I figured there are vitamins in the skin and it's just too much trouble.  Obviously, this makes it harder to eat, but it is fine this way too.  I like the baking with breadcrumbs method.  I did not salt or soak the eggplant first, and it wasn't at all bitter.  Made a quick garlicky marinara sauce to go with it, and I'll have great leftovers for days.  Good luck!

Starlet

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/100877.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'd never made eggplant parm before and wasn't sure what to expect, but this came out great! I took other reviewers advice and sea salted the slices and 'sweated' them for 20 m (they really do sweat!) then rinsed, dried and proceeded witht the recipe. I baked the breaded slices on a broiler pan so it would crisp up more evenly and I wouldn't have to flip them, baked 20m, and I'm no eggplant expert, but I feel like 10 wouldn't be long enough. I used a romano/parm blend, thinly sliced mozzarella and leftover home-made red sauce. I have to say though, using a low quality sauce could easily ruin this dish, so make your own or buy a good one. I've been trying to make more meat-less meals lately and this makes me not even miss the meat!  Healthy and hearty. I'm going to make this and AR's World Best Lasagna for a big Italian family dinner this weekend.  Thanks!

country:

text:
Holy smokes! This is soooo incredibly awesome that I ate the entire pan by myself within a week: that hardly ever happens. Since I only cook for myself, I only used 2 eggplants and had PLENTY. I took reviewers advice and sweated the eggplant slices with salt. I didn't have basil on hand, so no topping for me. Also I had plain breadcrumbs and italian seasoning; mix the two = italian breadcrumbs. Lastly, I have a tried and true method of coating food with flour for frying/baking, in this order: first flour, then egg mixture, then flour (or cornmeal or whatever the recipe calls for). Supposedly the coating stays on better with the first dip of flour. I hope this helps somehow.

text:
Very good! The first night we had it it was just okay. (I have a few modifications I'll make next time to make it better for us.) I took the leftovers to work a few days later and to my surprise, it was much improved after sitting in the fridge for a day or two! Loved it. Convinced me to make it again.   My changes: 1. Use seasoned oat flour instead of breadcrumbs to coat the eggplant. (Great if you're on a no-flour diet) 2. Slice eggplant no more than 1/4 - thinner will crisp up even faster. 3. Next time I will try pan-frying the eggplant to get them nice and crispy so they aren't soggy after baking.

text:
Like most other people, I initially bake the eggplant for more than suggested- about 10 minutes on each side.  As far as ingredients are concerned, I use 1 Eggplant, 1 26oz can of sauce, and a bit less than a bag of shredded mozzarella.  I also substitute egg beaters for eggs. I like to throw some pasta on the stove while cooking and serve the Eggplant over a bed of pasta.  It all also tastes great heated as leftovers.

text:
This was WONDERFUL!  I scaled it back, using 1 large eggplant, 1 jar of sauce - but added more cheese. Still filled a 9X13 pan.  I peeled and VERY thinly sliced the eggplant (1/8") and soaked in cold and salted water. Drained and let sit in the fridge overnight.  DH coated the Egglant in egg whites and self-made seasoned breadcrumbs (garlic powder, salt, pepper, parmesan, breadcrumb)using the baggie method (threw the slices in the egg white baggie then dumped the whole thing in the breadcrumb baggie and shook) baked on EVOO brushed on parchment lined sheet and assembled. Baked for 30 min. covered with tinfoil, then broiled for 5 min.  Served with garlic bread baked in breadmaker through the day and spaghetti noodles.  Thanks!

text:
I would give the recipe five stars...but this e-parm takes a bit of work.  You have to sweat the eggplant with sea salt after peeling/slicing for 20-30 minutes.  Rinse very well.  Then, pat DRY.  I used about 1 and 1/2 jars of sauce.  Definitely bake the slices TEN minutes on each side before putting the dish together.  I used grated Parm and Romano.  This recipe is sooo good when done.  Definitely a keeper :)

text:
Very good!!!!  I made the mistake of cutting the eggplant to thin and then baking for 10 minutes which was too long. The slices were too crispy and took away from the flavor of the eggplant.  I salted the slices with sea salt before dipping into the egg and bread crumbs.  I didn't have italian bread crumbs so mixed in some Italian seasoning in to regular bread crumbs.  Will make this again!

text:
Delicious!  Way better than the eggplant parmesan at a local Italian restaurant.  We had enough eggplant that we made a 9x13 pan plus an 11x7 pan. Baked it about 7-8 min per side. Had 1 good sized eggplant and it made a 15 in pan with 1 and a half layers. We sliced it about 1/4 inch thick. Served it with a salad and garlic bread and everyone enjoyed it!

userID:
2222528
Display Name:
A.S.G.
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
96
favoritesCount:
72
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the first time I've made eggplant parmesan, a dish I've only ever eaten at my Italian in-laws' house.  I've never liked it, but since my neighbor gave me a few eggplant I felt like I should do something with them.

After slaving away coating and baking tray after tray of eggplant (my slices were very small, having come from rather skinny eggplants), I was ready to pitch the whole idea and order pizza.  However, once dinner was on the table I changed my mind.  WOW!  This was soooo good!  All this time I thought I didn't like eggplant parmesan!  Baking the eggplant cut back so much on the "grease" factor, and the eggplant sliced retained some of their crispness after baking.  I did slice them quite thin, which my husband prefers.  Even my in-laws were very complimentary of this dish!  I followed the recipe almost exactly, only adding Italian seasonings and fresh ground black pepper to the breadcrumbs.  It also took 4 eggs to coat the eggplant, not two.  Baked the eggplant slices for ten minutes per side, as others suggested.  For the sauce, I used home-made tomato sauce from my garden.  The recipe is Homemade Tomato Sauce I here on allrecipes.  The result was fantastic, and I'll be making this again!  Great recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

The recipe called for pretty much twice as much bread crumbs as were really necessary, and the three large eggplants I sliced were WAY too much - next time I will use maybe one large and one smaller one. Other than that, this recipe was perfect and easy to make.

This is an AWESOME dish.  I first made it when I was still living at home, in high school.  My meat and potatoes parents loved it! text:
WOW! So simple and delicious. Following the review by NDG42200, I used 1 large eggplant (= 30 1/4 inch slices) and started by sweating the slices. I breaded and then baked them at 350 for 10 minutes on each side (perfect!). I then followed the recipe, deviating only in that I added 1 tsp chili powder, 1 tsp onion powder, and 1 tsp garlic powder to 2 bottles of store bought spaghetti sauces to add a bit more flavor. Baked 35 minutes. WOW! It bears repeating so I'll say it again: WOW!

DELICIOUS! I didn't change a thing, except that I added 3/4c. reduced-fat feta cheese in between two of the layers of eggplant. Also, I found that since I used fresh eggplant with firm skin and flesh, I didn't have a problem with bitterness at all. Thanks for the post!

Oh how my husnand loves this meal!!  He would eat it every night if he could.  I usually salt the eggplant for about 20 minutes before breading and baking.  It will sweat out some moisture so just brush off the salt and collected fluid before proceeding.  Also, I have used the italian breadcrumbs and am wondering if panko might be better.  We tend to keep the jars of tomato sauce around and I prefer to eat this dish with the more basic marinara sauces vs the more flavored ones (mushrooms, spicy, cheesy, etc) - I think it takes away from the good eggplant flavor.  Pair it with a salad and you have a great meal.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2007-12-29T18:50:24.443
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
510582
Display Name:
CARIECOLEMAN
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
An All-Star Recipe! The eggplant was crisp, tasty, easy and healthful. 

I made my own breadcrumbs with day-old ciabatta, by pulsing it in my food processor, roasting them in a dry frying pan, adding oregano at the end. At the same time, I pulsed one clove of garlic then added the bread crumbs and pulsed for a few more seconds. The crumbs were of various sizes and provided extra texture to the coating. Next time, I would consider adding grated parmesan to the breadcrumb mixture.

I cooked the 1/2 inch sliced eggplant for 10-min a side at 450 and was thoroughly pleased with the crispy texture. I will definitely be making this recipe again!

I love Eggplant Parmesan but cheated a little because instead of breading the eggplant I just brushed olive oil on both sides of the 1/2" slices and baked for 10 mins/side.  I also used Bryan's Sweet & Hot Pasta Sauce from this site instead of jarred sauce.  Saved some calories by not breading and I was satisfied with the results.  Oh...I also peeled the eggplant.  I think the peel can be a little bitter and I don't care for the texture of it anyway.

text:
I will probably make this one again if I am in the mood for eggplant. I prefer the vegetarian moussaka that can be found on this site as well and also uses eggplant however this recipe is simpler than the mossaka. I followed other users instructions and removed the excess water with salt and baked the eggplant for 10 minutes on each side.  I also added feta cheese.  I think that I will add spinach next time as I have seen this in another recipe and I think that it would be good.

I hate to say it, but I'm with Sandi.  Although I brushed the eggplant pieces with a little olive oil before I placing them in the oven, the entire dish turned out extremely dry.  It definitely needs a little more moisture if you are planning on baking your eggplant pieces twice.  Possibly use a slightly thin spaghetti sauce to accommodate?  I think I will stick with frying my eggplant, and just *try* to eat it less often.

text:
Easy and tasty!  I followed the directions almost exactly, although I did adjust some of the amounts for two people.  I followed some of the advice here and put salt on both sides of the eggplant slices.  I rinsed after I had prepared everything.

I used jarred sauce...Ragu's Chopped Tomato, Garlic, and Olive Oil.  It was a perfect choice.

I think the slices need to be thinner than I made them, as eggplant parm is usually softer than mine came out.  However, it was great for my first attempt and I will make this easy recipe again.

Thank you for sharing!

My first time using eggplant. I have tasted Eggplant Parmesan before, so I had an idea about what taste I was aiming for. I served it over spaghetti noodles. This dish was not a hit with my guests and I really think it was b/c the eggplant needed to be baked longer prior to adding it to the dish and maybe even longer in the oven. text:
It was okay, but I have a few changes that I think would make it better. Firstly, more mozzerella... the parmesan doesn't need to be as much, you can still taste it. Also, I would bake the eggplant slices for longer if I make this again, they were sort of hard. Although the recipe says peel the eggplants, I only peeled two and left the thrid unpeeled and it was great. Also, it took me almost two hours to prepare it, much longer than the original recipe states. Although I may never make it again, it was pretty good. Overall, just kind of so-so.

text:
Just had this for lunch and it was difficult to have only one portion!

I thought I had more Parmesan in the fridge than I actually did so I mixed what I had with some cheddar and it worked just as well.


I used 2 jars of Classico Tomato-Basil sauce which I use for my lasagne and other similar dishes. 

I chose to try this recipe because I could sidestep the frying and spattering and all that extra oil that is usually needed.  No mess - wonderful!

This is the way I am going to make Eggplant Parmesan from now on.  I still get the breading that I love but I can skip all the fat!

Wonderwabbit

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay dish but not great.  I kept the skin on because I likes my eggplant skin.  Also, you need to BOIL THE EGGPLANT for at least 30 minutes before you begin!  Most people underestimate the toughness of this wily veggie and that results in a bad dish.  Eggplant is best served soft, to the point of mushy.  If you slice it too thin and then bake, it'll just be dry.  Also the recipe called for way too much sauce, it drowned everything.  Next time, I'll stick with the old fried way.
Review:

region:

country:
None
text:
This was awesome! I only had one eggplant so I made this as a co-dish with pasta. I sliced the eggplant lenghtwise and very thin (I got 13 slices from one eggplant).  I did spary the baking pans with a no fat cooking spray, but would also spread olive oil with a paper towel as another option.  It baked perfectly in 5 mins on each side.  Also, I alternanted my cheeses with each layer ending with mozerella on top.  I did not put much cheese in the layers and saved most for the topping.  This was yummy and heathly!!  A definite keeper!!!

text:
I wanted to try this eggplant parm because it seemed so much better for you. Well the only way I could get the eggplant to brown in the oven and get soft was to drizzle olive oil on all of them. They do take about 15 minutes on each side as well so this is very time consuming recipe. It did taste great but I'm not sure mine was that much healthier then the fried version due to the added oil. As usual with most casseroles it tasted much better the next day.

None
text:
This was my first attempt at making eggplant parmesan.  I realize this is listed as a vegetarian meal; however, I added lean ground beef.  To reduce the high sodium content, I omitted the Italian Bread Crumbs and used yellow cornmeal which I flavored with Mrs. Dash italian seasoning mix.  I also added some cottage cheese.  My husband was surprised at how good this tasted, but he said it's missing "something".  Not sure what it is!  I plan to try this one again using ground chicken or turkey and soy cheeses.  Thanks Dolores!
